paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden moved on Wednesday to bolster the American nuclear umbrella guarding South Korea and vowed that any nuclear attack by North Korea would “result in the end” of the government in Pyongyang, underscoring a broad turn from diplomacy to deterrence in response to the threat from the volatile dictatorship.

headline: Biden’s 2024 Campaign Begins. You Might Miss It at First.
abstract: The president has no immediate plans to barnstorm key states with large rallies. He will instead try to burnish his record, and hope Republican infighting continues.
paragraph: President Biden has formally moved from a campaign-in-waiting to a campaign of waiting.

headline: Inside Biden’s Renewed Promise to Protect South Korea From Nuclear Weapons
abstract: President Biden’s emphasis on America’s willingness to defend South Korea is a striking admission that North Korea’s arsenal is here to stay.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the four years since President Donald J. Trump’s leader-to-leader diplomacy with Kim Jong-un of North Korea collapsed after a failed meeting in Hanoi, the North’s arsenal of nuclear weapons has expanded so fast that American and South Korean officials admit they have stopped trying to keep a precise count.

headline: Chief Justice Declines to Testify Before Congress Over Ethics Concerns
abstract: In an accompanying statement on ethics practices, the Supreme Court’s justices insisted their current ethical guidelines on gifts, travel and financial deals are sufficient.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee in a letter released Tuesday evening that he was declining its invitation to testify about ethics rules for the Supreme Court.

headline: Ad Flap Leaves Bitter Aftertaste for Bud Light and Warning for Big Business
abstract: Bud Light’s marketing effort with a transgender influencer has put it “in the center of the culture wars in a way that no company could possibly want to be,” one observer said.
paragraph: When she was named Anheuser-Busch’s marketing vice president, Alissa Heinerscheid explained in a recent podcast interview, “I had this super clear mandate: We need to evolve and elevate this incredibly iconic brand.” Doing that, she said, “means having a campaign that’s truly inclusive.”

headline: With Biden’s 2024 Bid, Kamala Harris Will Be Under More Scrutiny
abstract: The vice president will be central to President Biden’s re-election efforts, particularly on the issue of abortion access. Both critics and supporters say the increased spotlight is a good thing.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kamala Harris, the vice president, was featured heavily throughout a video that President Biden used to announce his 2024 campaign on Tuesday, a strong signal that she will be a central part of his re-election efforts.

headline: Biden Is Running on His Record (and Away From It)
abstract: President Biden has acknowledged that he has not accomplished all he wished to. But that, he maintains, is an argument for his re-election.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just hours after formally kicking off his re-election campaign, President Biden appeared on Tuesday before a crowd of union supporters chanting “four more years” to outline his case for a second term.

headline: Don’t Call It a ‘Cut’: G.O.P. Tries to Rebrand Its Plan to Reduce Spending
abstract: House Republicans pitched their 2011 debt limit bill aggressively, trumpeting a zeal for deep spending cuts. Their latest fiscal plan tiptoes around them, with a milder slogan to match.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2011, as a wave of populist fervor swept through Congress, delivering a restive class of anti-spending Republicans who had no appetite for raising the debt limit, House G.O.P. leaders rallied their members around a bill with a blunt, snappy slogan: “Cut, Cap and Balance.”

headline: Biden Says ‘MAGA Extremists Are Cut From a Different Cloth’
abstract: In his first public speech since announcing his re-election bid, President Biden called himself “the most pro-union president in American history” and said that Republicans support an agenda that favors the rich.
paragraph: In his first public speech since announcing his re-election bid, President Biden called himself “the most pro-union president in American history” and said that Republicans support an agenda that favors the rich.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Biden’s Campaign Manager, Julie Chávez Rodríguez
abstract: Ms. Chávez Rodríguez, a veteran of the Obama administration and of Vice President Kamala Harris’s political orbit, is taking on one of the most intense and scrutinized jobs in American politics.
paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday named Julie Chávez Rodríguez as the campaign manager for his re-election effort, elevating a senior adviser and the highest-ranking Latina in the White House to one of the most intense and scrutinized jobs in American politics.

headline: An Early, Early Look at Biden’s 2024 Prospects
abstract: Almost every recent poll shows a highly competitive presidential race.
paragraph: With Donald J. Trump indicted, Ron DeSantis faltering in the polls and Democrats still basking in their strong midterm showing, some might feel that President Biden’s re-election is all but a done deal.

headline: Analysis: Biden Faces Headwinds, but Democrats See Reasons for Optimism
abstract: President Biden’s poll numbers remain low, but structural advantages have Democrats insisting he is far better positioned than his Republican rivals.
paragraph: Nearly seven in 10 Americans believe their country is on a “wrong track.” The incumbent president will be 81 on Election Day 2024. More than half of the voters in his own party don’t want him to run for re-election.

headline: Biden Announces Re-Election Bid for 2024
abstract: President Biden formally declared his candidacy for a second term in a campaign video posted to his social media accounts.
paragraph: President Biden formally declared his candidacy for a second term in a campaign video posted to his social media accounts.

headline: Biden Announces Re-election Bid, Defying Trump and History
abstract: While the president once pitched himself as “a bridge” to a new generation of Democratic leaders, he has decided that he is not ready to turn the torch over yet.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden formally announced on Tuesday that he would seek a second term, arguing that American democracy still faces a profound threat from former President Donald J. Trump as he set up the possibility of a climactic rematch between the two next year.

headline: Republicans Did Something Most People Don’t Like, So They’re Changing the Rules
abstract: The party has opened fronts in the war for minority rule.
paragraph: When Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and United Nations ambassador, announced her campaign for the Republican presidential nomination in February, she remarked that the Republican Party had “lost the popular vote in seven out of the last eight presidential elections.” That, she said, “has to change.”

headline: Rallying union workers, Biden opens his 2024 campaign. Here’s the latest.
abstract: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced his bid for a second four-year term in a video posted online Tuesday morning, urging voters to let him “finish this job” and setting in motion a possible rematch with former President Donald J. Trump.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced his bid for a second four-year term in a video posted online Tuesday morning, urging voters to let him “finish this job” and setting in motion a possible rematch with former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Major G.O.P. Donor’s Commitment to DeSantis Is Murkier Than Thought
abstract: The hedge fund billionaire Kenneth Griffin, who seemed set to be a powerful financial backer of the Florida governor, is said to still be evaluating the Republican primary race.
paragraph: Nearly six months ago, Kenneth Griffin, the Republican megadonor and hedge fund executive, seemed poised to be a powerful financial backer of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida in his anticipated run for president.

headline: The Group That Searches for Missing Ukrainian Children
abstract: Save Ukraine’s mission includes reuniting families victimized by Russia’s deportations in occupied areas.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Russian Army took Kherson in southern Ukraine, the occupation authorities offered 16-year-old Anastasia a chance to go to Crimea, a holiday away from war, the officials told her mother.

headline: Commerce Dept. Outlines Plans to Fund Cutting-Edge Chip Research
abstract: The Biden administration announced its strategy for the National Semiconductor Technology Center, a string of facilities aimed at propelling U.S. innovation.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration outlined plans on Tuesday to propel research on the type of cutting-edge microchips needed to power computers, cars and other devices, saying it would establish a new national organization with locations in various parts of the United States.

headline: Money in Politics: Overlooked Financial Figures
abstract: A recent campaign finance deadline produced a trove of information about U.S. politicians, but most headlines focused on the biggest names. Here’s some of what flew under the radar.
paragraph: A recent campaign finance deadline produced a trove of information about U.S. politicians, but most headlines focused on the biggest names. Here’s some of what flew under the radar.

headline: The Tragedy of Fox News
abstract: It could have steered conservatives in a better direction.
paragraph: In the summer of 2011, Rupert Murdoch stopped by my small office at The Wall Street Journal, where I was a columnist and editor. He was just back from London, where he had given testimony to a parliamentary committee investigating the phone-hacking scandal by his British tabloids (and where he was attacked with a shaving-foam pie). The scandal ultimately resulted in the closure of News of the World, at one point one of the world’s biggest-selling English-language newspapers.

headline: The College Board Will Change Its A.P. African American Studies Course
abstract: The course had run into criticism from scholars, who accused the board of omitting key concepts and bending to political pressure from Gov. Ron DeSantis.
paragraph: The College Board said on Monday that it would revise its Advanced Placement African American studies course, less than three months after releasing it to a barrage of criticism from scholars, who accused the board of omitting key concepts and bending to political pressure from Gov. Ron DeSantis, who had said he would not approve the curriculum for use in Florida.

headline: Trump Is Endorsed by a Senator With Sway on Republican Donors
abstract: Steve Daines of Montana, the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, cited the former president’s accomplishments on issues like immigration.
paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has secured one of his most important Capitol Hill endorsements for a 2024 presidential bid: Senator Steve Daines of Montana, the chairman of the Senate Republicans’ campaign arm.

headline: Guantánamo Prosecutor Seeks 2025 Trial in Bali Bombing Case
abstract: The U.S. has held the men as suspects since 2003; prosecutors said government agencies are still processing trial evidence for national security reasons.
paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A prosecutor on Monday proposed a March 2025 trial date for three men accused of conspiring in the 2002 nightclub bombings in Bali, Indonesia, and pledged to present the military judge with all proposed national security evidence in the case in the next nine months.

headline: Prosecution and Defense Sum Up at Proud Boys Jan. 6 Sedition Trial
abstract: Defense lawyers at the trial of five members of the far-right group argued that prosecutors had failed to prove the Proud Boys were carrying out a plan when they stormed the Capitol.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors at the sedition trial of five members of the Proud Boys made a final pitch to the jury on Monday, arguing that the defendants — acting as “Donald Trump’s army” — conspired to keep Mr. Trump in office after the 2020 election by leading a mob in a violent attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: I.R.S. Official Is Said to Assert Political Meddling in Hunter Biden Inquiry
abstract: An agent overseeing the agency’s portion of the investigation into the president’s son is asking Congress for whistle-blower protection to discuss what he says is misconduct in the case.
paragraph: As Justice Department officials weigh whether to indict Hunter Biden, the investigator overseeing the Internal Revenue Service’s portion of the case has come forward with allegations of political favoritism in the inquiry that stand to add to the already fraught circumstances facing the department.

headline: Biden Plans an Election Bid That Will Be More Complicated the 2nd Time Around
abstract: The president’s mission will be to defend his record while warning about the dangers of Donald J. Trump’s return.
paragraph: Follow our live updates on Biden’s re-election campaign announcement.

headline: Susan Rice to Step Down as Biden’s Domestic Policy Adviser
abstract: Ms. Rice oversaw some of the Biden administration’s most polarizing issues, including gun control, student loan relief and immigration.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Susan Rice, President Biden’s domestic policy adviser, will step down next month after overseeing some of the administration’s most polarizing issues, including immigration, gun control and student loan relief, the White House announced on Monday.

headline: What Scalia’s Defense of a Free Jet Trip Says About Thomas’s Travels
abstract: In a combative 2004 memo rejecting calls for his recusal, Justice Antonin Scalia discussed whether a trip on a litigant’s plane was a gift that had to be disclosed.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost 20 years ago, during the Supreme Court’s winter break in 2004, Justice Antonin Scalia took a free trip on a Gulfstream jet, hitching a ride with Vice President Dick Cheney on a government plane. The two men were going duck hunting in Louisiana.

headline: How Democrats Learned to Cast Aside Reservations and Embrace Biden 2024
abstract: The president, who is expected to formally announce his re-election campaign this week, has won the full support of his party despite questions about his age and middling approval ratings.
paragraph: [For updates on President Biden’s bid for a second term, which was formally announced on Tuesday, read our live coverage.]

headline: Biden Has Something He’d Like to Tell You
abstract: And it can’t wait any longer.
paragraph: Gail Collins: Well, Bret, it looks like Joe Biden will be announcing his re-election bid this week.

headline: Christie, in New Hampshire, Reconnects With 2016 Supporters
abstract: The former New Jersey governor is testing a campaign as Donald Trump’s most vocal critic in the Republican field.
paragraph: Don’t ask Chris Christie what “lane” there is for him in the Republican primary. Don’t ask how someone polling at 1 percent, who is sharply critical of Donald J. Trump, could possibly win the 2024 nomination when the party base has no tolerance for attacks on the former president.

headline: Republicans Call for Censure of Transgender Lawmaker Who Condemned Care Ban
abstract: Rep. Zooey Zephyr, a Democratic state representative in Montana, pleaded for her colleagues to reject a bill that would ban transition care for transgender minors. Republicans misgendered her and called for her to be censured.
paragraph: Representative Zooey Zephyr took to the floor of the Montana Legislature on Tuesday to make an impassioned plea for her colleagues to reject a bill that would ban transition care for transgender minors, saying that denying such care would be “tantamount to torture.”

headline: Bud Shuster, Unabashed ‘Asphalt King’ of Congress, Dies at 91
abstract: A Pennsylvania Republican, he targeted a disproportionate share of federal highway funds to his Appalachian district during his 28 years in the House.
paragraph: Bud Shuster, a former longtime Republican congressman from Pennsylvania who was crowned the “king of asphalt” because he funneled billions of dollars in gasoline tax revenue to his Appalachian district for highway construction, died on Wednesday at his farm in Everett, Pa. He was 91.

headline: Anti-Abortion Group Urges Trump to Endorse a National Ban
abstract: Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America, seeking a ban after 15 weeks of pregnancy, threatened to campaign against any candidate who does not support the proposal.
paragraph: Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America, a prominent anti-abortion political group, threatened on Thursday to campaign against Donald J. Trump unless he endorsed a national ban on abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, a bold challenge that exposed the rift between the former president and some of his onetime allies.

headline: Defendant Lashes Out From Witness Stand During Proud Boys Trial
abstract: Dominic Pezzola, who has been indicted on charges of seditious conspiracy in the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, attacked prosecutors for bringing “fake charges” against him.
paragraph: A defendant in the Proud Boys seditious conspiracy case lashed out at prosecutors from the witness stand on Thursday, attacking them for conducting what he described as a “corrupt trial” marred by “fake charges.”

headline: Signed Letters, Mar-a-Lago Dinners: Trump’s Personal Touch in Fighting DeSantis
abstract: The former president has found a way to connect with Florida’s congressional delegation in a way that Gov. Ron DeSantis has not.
paragraph: When Anna Paulina Luna’s father was killed in a car crash in January 2022, she received notes from two prominent Florida Republicans.

headline: House Votes to Block Transgender Athletes From Female Sports Teams
abstract: The Republican-backed bill would prohibit athletes who have transitioned from male to female from competing in women’s sports.
paragraph: The Republican-backed bill would prohibit athletes who have transitioned from male to female from competing in women’s sports.

headline: What the Science Says About ‘Don’t Say Gay’ and Young People
abstract: Laws like the Florida bill will cause harm whether or not direct censorship takes place.
paragraph: Florida Republicans on Wednesday expanded a state law that prohibits classroom instruction on L.G.B.T.Q. subjects through third grade. Now the “Don’t Say Gay” law will also apply to students in grades four to 12.

headline: Jan. 6 Defendant Opens Fire on Deputies Before Surrender to the F.B.I.
abstract: The Texas man, who had been charged with misdemeanors for entering the Capitol, was arrested on a felony count of shooting at local law enforcement officers.
paragraph: A Texas man who was facing charges for taking part in the storming of the Capitol opened fire on local sheriff’s deputies this week as they went to check on him on the day he was scheduled to surrender to the F.B.I., federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: ‘Prove Mike Wrong’ for $5 Million, Lindell Pitched. Now He’s Told to Pay Up.
abstract: An arbitration panel ruled that the MyPillow founder had failed to pay a computer software expert who disproved his false election claims as part of a contest.
paragraph: Mike Lindell, the MyPillow founder and Trump ally who has been a leading voice in pushing conspiracy theories about the 2020 presidential election, must pay $5 million to a software forensics expert who debunked a series of false claims as part of a “Prove Mike Wrong” contest, an arbitration panel said on Wednesday.

headline: The Grand Canyon, a Cathedral to Time, Is Losing Its River
abstract: The Colorado River, which carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years, is now in crisis from climate change and overuse.
paragraph: The Colorado River, which carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years, is now in crisis from climate change and overuse.

headline: Nature Lawyers Up
abstract: A growing number of countries and courts say the environment should be endowed with legal rights.
paragraph: Overall, humanity has made a lot of progress, albeit uneven, over the past decades. Our environment, on the other hand, might be in worse shape than ever. So, what if we all agreed that nature had basic rights similar to human rights?

headline: The Debt Limit Deal and Climate Action
abstract: Tucked into the measure are changes to how the government approves projects at the center of the country’s climate goals.
paragraph: President Biden and Congress have wrangled a big political deal to raise the country’s debt ceiling.

headline: Climate Shocks Are Making Parts of America Uninsurable. It Just Got Worse.
abstract: The largest insurer in California said it would stop offering new coverage. It’s part of a broader trend of companies pulling back from dangerous areas.
paragraph: The climate crisis is becoming a financial crisis.

headline: Arctic Summer Could Be Practically Sea-Ice-Free by the 2030s
abstract: In a new study, scientists found that the climate milestone could come about a decade sooner than anticipated, even if planet-warming emissions are gradually reduced.
paragraph: The first summer on record that melts practically all of the Arctic’s floating sea ice could occur as early as the 2030s, according to a new scientific study — about a decade sooner than researchers previously predicted.

headline: It’s Called the Grand Canyon, Not the Eternal Canyon
abstract: A rafting trip yields insights about a national treasure that seems permanent but is always being changed, lately by humans.
paragraph: You don’t need me to tell you that the Grand Canyon is magnificent. Otherworldly. Sublime. But, having rafted through 90 miles of the canyon with a group of scientists and grad students, I can tell you that it’s quite a bit more fragile, and less permanent, than you might think.

headline: Biden Administration Bans Drilling Around Native American Cultural Site
abstract: The Interior Department will withdraw public lands around Chaco Canyon from new oil and gas leasing for 20 years.
paragraph: The Biden administration took action on Friday to block new oil and gas leasing on federal land around Chaco Canyon in New Mexico, one of the nation’s oldest and most culturally significant Native American sites. Interior Secretary Deb Haaland announced that her agency would withdraw public lands within a 10-mile radius of Chaco Canyon and the area around it, known as Chaco Culture National Historical Park, from access to new oil and gas leasing for 20 years, following through on a 2021 pledge by President Biden to protect the area from drilling. The move will not affect existing oil and gas leases on the land or drilling on private property within the 10-mile radius.

headline: Two Dead Humpback Whales Are Seen Off Coast of New York
abstract: The animals, observed floating off Long Island and Staten Island this week, were the latest casualties of a species that faces many threats.
paragraph: Two dead humpback whales have been spotted floating in waters not far from New York City, the federal authorities said on Thursday, in another worrying sign for a species that faces a number of threats.

headline: You’ve Never Heard of Him, but He’s Remaking the Pollution Fight
abstract: Richard Revesz is changing the way the government calculates the cost and benefits of regulation, with far-reaching implications for climate change.
paragraph: This spring the Biden administration proposed or implemented eight major environmental regulations, including the nation’s toughest climate rule, rolling out what experts say are the most ambitious limits on polluting industries by the government in a single season.

headline: How to Start Birding
abstract: Alli Smith, of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, offers beginner tips for exploring the wide world of birds.
paragraph: This summer, as part of The New York Times birding project, The Times will be sharing a series of prompts to help readers learn how to get started birding. Begin with something foundational: Learn to identify a few of the birds most commonly seen near where you live.

headline: The Mystery of the Vanishing Kestrels: What’s Happening to This Flashy Falcon?
abstract: The number of American kestrels has dropped sharply. That goes against the trend for birds of prey, broadly seen as a conservation bright spot.
paragraph: At first, people thought it might be a housing shortage.

headline: G.M. and Stellantis Paid $364 Million in Fuel Economy Fines
abstract: The automakers paid the federal government for falling short of efficiency standards for cars and trucks in recent years.
paragraph: General Motors and Stellantis paid a combined $363.8 million in penalties for failing to meet federal fuel-economy standards for cars and trucks they produced in previous years, according to federal government documents posted on Friday.

headline: Birds With a Taste for Flesh Threaten Whale Calves
abstract: In Argentina, kelp gulls are attacking the backs of southern right whales, imperiling the recovery of an endangered species.
paragraph: Thousands of colossal southern right whales travel to the calm waters of Península Valdés off the coast of Argentina each year to breed and give birth. The cetaceans, which can reach 56 feet in length, are a sight to behold, especially with their calves in tow. But if you venture out to see them, you may sometimes find your stomach turning for a reason that has nothing to do with sea sickness.

headline: Put a Bird on It? Ancient Egypt Was Way Ahead of Us.
abstract: A 3,300-year-old palace mural offers an exquisitely detailed view of several bird species, and presents an artistic mystery.
paragraph: A century ago, archaeologists excavated a 3,300-year-old Egyptian palace in Amarna, which was fleetingly the capital of Egypt during the reign of the pharaoh Akhenaten. Situated far from the crowded areas of Amarna, the North Palace offered a quiet retreat for the royal family.

headline: An Avian Murder Case on a Quiet Back Porch
abstract: A nest was assaulted. Was it the cowbird or the sparrow?
paragraph: I open the pantry door and the eastern phoebe flies off the nest. Her cup-shaped home is made of mud, covered in moss and cantilevered over a glass light fixture — an avian Fallingwater. Her nest placement makes sense. Before eastern phoebes lived so close to humans, they built their nests on cliffs. Every year for 35 years, we’ve had an eastern phoebe nest under the eaves of our back porch. Without her, it would not be spring.

headline: Is It Wrong to Bring a Child Into Our Warming World?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on personal responsibility and climate change.
paragraph: I have always loved babies and children. I babysat throughout high school and college, and do so even now as a full-time engineer. My fiancé was drawn to me because of how much he appreciated my talent with and love for children. We have many little nieces, nephews and cousins whom we love but don’t get to see often. We also have always been clear with each other that we would try to have biological children soon after getting married.

headline: Russia and Saudi Arabia’s Oil Partnership Shows Strain
abstract: Analysts said the countries’ mutual need to keep energy prices high would help them maintain close ties, despite signs that Moscow has undercut previous deals.
paragraph: For most of the last six years, the leaders of Russia and Saudi Arabia worked with each other to control the global oil market during times of war, pandemic and dizzying price gyrations.

headline: Seven Underappreciated Birding Spots in New York
abstract: Sure, you know about Central Park and Flushing Meadows. But here are a few more birding locations worth checking out.
paragraph: Birding in New York City is easier than you might think. “The best place to bird in New York is exactly where you are right at that moment,” said Martha Harbison, a writer and vice president of the Feminist Bird Club. “I’ve observed 20 species from my own window. And I live in a very ungreen area of Brooklyn.”

headline: Debt Deal Includes a Green Light for a Contentious Pipeline
abstract: Climate activists are livid over a provision in the debt limit agreement that orders federal agencies to issue permits for the Mountain Valley Pipeline — and says courts can’t review them.
paragraph: Environmental activists are enraged by the deal struck between President Biden and Republicans to raise the debt ceiling because it would also expedite construction of a bitterly contested gas pipeline and includes unusual measures to insulate that project from judicial review.

headline: Arizona Limits Construction Around Phoenix as Its Water Supply Dwindles
abstract: In what could be a glimpse of the future as climate change batters the West, officials ruled there’s not enough groundwater for projects already approved.
paragraph: Arizona has determined that there is not enough groundwater for all of the housing construction that has already been approved in the Phoenix area, and will stop developers from building some new subdivisions, a sign of looming trouble in the West and other places where overuse, drought and climate change are straining water supplies.

headline: Testing New York Apartments: How Dirty Is That Gas Stove, Really?
abstract: Scientists are lugging sophisticated sensors into homes in 10 cities to measure and track the pollution from gas stoves as it drifts from room to room.
paragraph: Every morning, as millions of Americans light up the gas stoves in their kitchens to heat some water or griddle their hash browns, they aren’t just sending delicious breakfast smells wafting through their homes. The blue flames also emit harmful pollutants like nitrogen dioxides, as well as planet-warming gases.

headline: As U.S. Races Ahead, Europe Frets About Battery Factory Subsidies
abstract: The European Union is trying to assemble the building blocks to produce electric cars, but subsidies are luring companies to the United States.
paragraph: European leaders complained for years that the United States was not doing enough to fight climate change. Now that the Biden administration has devoted hundreds of billions of dollars to that cause, many Europeans are complaining that the United States is going about it the wrong way.

headline: Where Whales, Puffins and Icebergs Jostle for Your Attention
abstract: Each spring, opalescent icebergs from the Greenland ice sheet pass through Iceberg Alley, off the eastern edge of Canada, on a slow-motion journey southward.
paragraph: “I never trust the mind of an iceberg,” Cecil Stockley told me. He estimates its length, multiplies by five and keeps his boat at least that distance away.

headline: Finding Climate Solutions in a Spanish Village
abstract: Behind its rural facade, La Almunia de Doña Godina is doing its part to use technology to address climate change.
paragraph: LA ALMUNIA DE DOÑA GODINA, Spain — Crisscrossed by irrigation canals — one of which was built by the Moors in the Middle Ages — and surrounded by fields filled with peach, apple and cherry orchards, this place, at first glance, is a traditional fruit-farming village in northeast Spain.

headline: Someone to Know: The Entitled Cyclist
abstract: He’s trying to show that it really is possible to get out of your car, even in Los Angeles.
paragraph: Traffic jams might be the worst part of the day to many of you. Today, I want to introduce you to Tom Morash, an Angeleno who got tired of sitting in his car and decided to grab a bike instead.

headline: In the Bahamas, a Constant Race to Adapt to Climate Change
abstract: Rising seas and the ongoing threat of hurricanes and storm surges have forced the Caribbean nation to become a laboratory for climate adaptation.
paragraph: At the United Nations climate summit in Egypt last year, Prime Minister Philip Davis of the Bahamas emerged as one of the most impassioned speakers among the more than 100 heads of state in attendance.

headline: Just Between Us Squirrels, There Might Be Trouble in the Arctic Dating Scene
abstract: Climate change appears to be disrupting the hibernation of females in the Far North, scientists say, and that could affect mating season.
paragraph: Male Arctic ground squirrels go through puberty every year. As if that wasn’t hard enough, now the females have a problem, too.

headline: A Powerful Climate Solution Just Below the Ocean’s Surface
abstract: Restoring seagrass meadows is one tool that coastal communities can use to address climate change, both by capturing emissions and mitigating their effects.
paragraph: They can bolster the coastlines, break the force of hurtling waves, provide housing for fish, shellfish, and migrating birds, clean the water, store as much as 5 percent of the world’s carbon dioxide, and pump oxygen into the ocean, in part making it possible for life on Earth as we know it.

headline: Flood-Battered Italian Region May See More Violent and Frequent Storms
abstract: Experts have linked recent deadly rains in the north of the country to climate change, but decades of urbanization and neglect helped lay the groundwork for a calamity.
paragraph: The floods that submerged the northern Italian region of Emilia-Romagna this month, killing 15 people, leaving thousands homeless and grinding transportation and businesses to a halt, were not one-off events, warn experts, who predict that there are more similar, frequent and violent storms to come.

headline: How Extreme Heat Causes Cascading Crises
abstract: Power grids and hospitals can be overwhelmed, but there are fixes.
paragraph: Extreme heat can bring on some extremely dangerous feedback loops for American hospitals and clinics.

headline: Gasoline Prices, a Source of Pain Last Year, Have Come Way Down
abstract: Reasons include a stronger supply of oil and weaker-than-expected demand, energy experts say. Some people are saving hundreds of dollars on fuel.
paragraph: Americans who fill up their cars this Memorial Day weekend will catch a break — at least compared with a year ago, when gasoline prices were soaring.

headline: Hurricane Season Could Bring 12 to 17 Named Storms, Forecasters Say
abstract: Weather experts predicted a “near-normal” season, expecting a similar number of named tropical systems as in 2022, but there was uncertainty in the forecast.
paragraph: There could be from 12 to 17 named tropical cyclones this hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean, similar to the number of named storms last year and a “near-normal” amount, forecasters said.

headline: Supreme Court Limits E.P.A.’s Power to Address Water Pollution
abstract: Experts said the decision would sharply undercut the agency’s authority to protect millions of acres of wetlands under the Clean Water Act, leaving them subject to pollution without penalty.
paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday curtailed the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to police millions of acres of wetlands, delivering another setback to the agency’s ability to combat pollution.

headline: Behind the Scenes, G7 Nations Wrangle Over Ambitious Climate Commitments
abstract: The U.S. finds itself caught between defending President Biden’s climate change agenda and aiding allies intent on increasing their access to fossil fuels.
paragraph: In theory, the world’s largest industrialized democracies have agreed to stop using fossil fuels within a little over a quarter-century and to switch to new sources of power such as solar and wind as fast as they can.

headline: Heat Wave and Blackout Would Send Half of Phoenix to E.R., Study Says
abstract: New research warns that nearly 800,000 residents would need emergency medical care for heat stroke and other illnesses in an extended power failure. Other cities are also at risk.
paragraph: If a multiday blackout in Phoenix coincided with a heat wave, nearly half the population would require emergency department care for heat stroke or other heat-related illnesses, a new study suggests.

headline: Rice. Half of Humanity Eats It. And Climate Change Is Wrecking It.
abstract: From the Mississippi to the Mekong, farmers and researchers are finding creative fixes for the dire threats of global warming, extreme rains and sea-level rise.
paragraph: From the Mississippi to the Mekong, farmers and researchers are finding creative fixes for the dire threats of global warming, extreme rains and sea-level rise.

headline: Reimagining Rice, From the Mekong to the Mississippi
abstract: People around the world are exploring new ways to grow one of the world’s most important staple crops.
paragraph: Look inside my pantry any given week, and you’ll see rice paper for summer rolls, rice noodles for my slapdash version of pad Thai, a few packets of rice ramen, sake, rice wine vinegar, and rice cakes that the teenager likes to smear with peanut butter. There’s a bag of arborio for an occasional herby risotto, brown rice for rainy day khichdi, a basmati from Bryce Lundberg’s farm in Northern California, and a red rice that Anna McClung, a plant breeder, developed from a variety considered a weed.

headline: Alert Level Is Raised in Central Mexico as Volcano Spews Smoke and Ash
abstract: Officials were preparing evacuation routes and shelters around the volcano, Popocatépetl, and some schools and parks were closed to minimize exposure to falling ash.
paragraph: An alert level was raised on Sunday for a volcano in Central Mexico that was spewing ash and smoke, prompting officials to close schools and public parks, and to prepare for the possibility of evacuations.

headline: The Colorado River Is Shrinking. See What’s Using All the Water.
abstract: Hint: It’s less about long showers and more about what’s for dinner.
paragraph: Hint: It’s less about long showers and more about what’s for dinner.

headline: A Breakthrough Deal to Keep the Colorado River From Going Dry, for Now
abstract: The agreement on cuts, aided by a wet winter and $1.2 billion in federal payments, expires at the end of 2026.
paragraph: Arizona, California and Nevada have agreed to take less water from the drought-strained Colorado River, a breakthrough agreement that, for now, keeps the river from falling so low that it would jeopardize water supplies for major Western cities like Phoenix and Los Angeles as well as for some of America’s most productive farmland.

headline: Cities vs. Rising Seas
abstract: Around the world, tens of millions could lose their homes in the coming decades. Planning is the key to protecting them.
paragraph: What does a country do when rising seas threaten to swamp its coastal capital?

headline: Heat Will Likely Soar to Record Levels in Next 5 Years, New Analysis Says
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization forecast “far-reaching repercussions for health, food security, water management and the environment.”
paragraph: Global temperatures are likely to soar to record highs over the next five years, driven by human-caused warming and a climate pattern known as El Niño, forecasters at the World Meteorological Organization said on Wednesday.

headline: England’s Water Companies Vow to Clean Up Their Sewage Dumping Act
abstract: Private firms apologized for not doing more to prevent the release of untreated sewage into rivers and seas and pledged to invest 10 billion pounds to fix the problem.
paragraph: England’s rivers and coastlines have long endured a foul problem — an astounding release of untreated sewage by water companies, some of it illegal, which critics say has sickened swimmers and polluted the country’s critical ecosystems.

headline: Canada’s Wildfires Have Been Disrupting Lives. Now, Oil and Gas Take a Hit.
abstract: Alberta’s vast oil industry is cutting production as the flames menace wells and pipelines, highlighting the danger
paragraph: Wildfires sweeping across western Canada that have driven thousands of people from their homes are also striking the heart of Canadian oil and gas country, forcing companies to curb production.

headline: A Vanished Bird Might Live On, or Not. The Video Is Grainy.
abstract: Scientists say they’ve compiled evidence showing that the ivory-billed woodpecker, a kind of Holy Grail for American birders, still exists.
paragraph: If there’s new hope, it’s blurry. What’s certain: The roller coaster tale of the ivory-billed woodpecker, a majestic bird whose presumed extinction has been punctuated by a series of contested rediscoveries, is going strong.

headline: Go Birding With The Times
abstract: Shifts in bird populations can be a sign of a changing climate. This summer, help scientists learn about the birds in your area.
paragraph: Our understanding of birds has been profoundly shaped by the work of everyday people. After all, anyone can step outside and pay attention to an untamed world swooping above.

headline: E.P.A. Announces Crackdown on Toxic Coal Ash From Landfills
abstract: Hundreds of landfills containing toxic coal ash have gone unregulated for years, posing hazards to human health and the environment.
paragraph: The Biden administration is moving to close a loophole that had exempted hundreds of inactive coal ash landfills from rules designed to prevent heavy metals like mercury and arsenic from seeping into groundwater, the Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday.

headline: Climate Change Brings Warmer, Wetter Weather to Trinidad
abstract: Even as the leaders of Trinidad and Tobago double down on fossil fuels, climate change is bringing more extreme weather to the island nation.
paragraph: Imtiaz Khan remembers the rains of his childhood as being light and providing welcome relief from the summer heat. A heavy shower, he said, would arrive only about once a month during the rainy season.

headline: Biden Administration Approves Key Permit for West Virginia Gas Pipeline
abstract: The Mountain Valley line, which would carry gas from West Virginia to Virginia, still faces legal and regulatory hurdles.
paragraph: The Biden administration has granted a crucial permit for the Mountain Valley Pipeline, a project championed by Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, despite opposition from climate experts and environmental groups.

headline: The ‘Skeletons’ in Big Oil’s Closet
abstract: There’s growing evidence that fossil fuel companies knew their product would harm the climate, and that’s driving lawsuits around the world.
paragraph: The legal headaches for Big Oil are spreading. The latest company to land in court is Eni, the Italian giant.

headline: Burning Man Becomes Latest Adversary in Geothermal Feud
abstract: Festival organizers are trying to block plans to build a clean energy plant in the Nevada desert, highlighting the struggle to combat climate change and the cost of clean power.
paragraph: One of the darkest towns in America lies roughly 100 miles north of Reno, where the lights are few and rarely lit until one week each summer when pyrotechnics and LEDs set the sky and mountains aglow.

headline: Electric Vans, Delayed by Production Problems, Find Eager Buyers
abstract: Passenger cars dominate the electric vehicle market, but light delivery trucks could benefit from the cost savings and range E.V.s offer.
paragraph: Not long after buying a Ford E-Transit van for his plumbing business last November, Mitch Smedley sat down with some receipts and a calculator to figure out how much the electric vehicle was saving him on fuel expenses.

headline: Why Some Countries Find It Hard to Move Away From Fossil Fuels
abstract: Trinidad and Tobago is the No. 2 exporter of liquefied natural gas in the Americas. Its output has been falling, but it remains committed to fossil fuels.
paragraph: Ribboned shovel in hand, Prime Minister Keith Rowley joined a ceremonial groundbreaking last month to celebrate Trinidad and Tobago’s first large solar farm project expected to generate power for 42,000 homes.

headline: Can the World Make an Electric Car Battery Without China?
abstract: From mines to refineries and factories, China began investing decades ago. Today, most of your electric car batteries are made in China and that’s unlikely to change soon.
paragraph: From mines to refineries and factories, China began investing decades ago. Today, most of your electric car batteries are made in China and that’s unlikely to change soon.

headline: Your DNA Can Now Be Pulled From Thin Air. Privacy Experts Are Worried.
abstract: Environmental DNA research has aided conservation, but scientists say its ability to glean information about human populations and individuals poses dangers.
paragraph: David Duffy, a wildlife geneticist at the University of Florida, just wanted a better way to track disease in sea turtles. Then he started finding human DNA everywhere he looked.

headline: Your Stories: Cool, Fascinating and Fun Climate Jobs
abstract: We asked you to tell us about your careers. You had plenty to say.
paragraph: Can you find a rewarding career in climate? Yes, definitely. How do we know? You told us.

headline: In a Climate Trade-Off, Biden Backs Manchin’s Fossil Fuel Plan
abstract: The White House hopes that the approval of some oil and gas projects will speed the expansion of transmission lines for renewable energy.
paragraph: The White House on Wednesday endorsed a plan by Senator Joe Manchin III to speed the approval of some fossil fuel projects in order to also hasten the construction of new transmission lines critical for meeting President Biden’s climate goals.

headline: E.P.A. Proposes First Limits on Climate Pollution From Existing Power Plants
abstract: It’s the last in a string of major regulations proposed by the Biden administration to sharply cut the greenhouse gases produced by the United States.
paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday announced the first regulations to limit greenhouse pollution from existing power plants, capping an unparalleled string of climate policies that, taken together, could substantially reduce the nation’s contribution to global warming.

headline: Flush With Federal Money, Strings Attached, a Deep South Factory Votes to Unionize
abstract: Friday’s victory by the United Steelworkers at a factory building electric school buses was a test for Democratic hopes that clean-energy funding from Washington could bolster organized labor.
paragraph: Workers at a rural Georgia factory that builds electric school buses under generous federal subsidies voted to unionize on Friday, handing organized labor and Democrats a surprise victory in their hopes to turn huge new infusions of money from Washington into a union beachhead in the Deep South.

headline: A Swaggering Clean-Energy Pioneer, With $400 Billion to Hand Out
abstract: Jigar Shah runs a federal program that suddenly has a gusher of money to lend before the next election.
paragraph: The hotel ballroom was packed before breakfast as Jigar Shah took the stage at the oil and gas industry’s annual conference in Houston this spring. The host joked he was confident a huge crowd would come out for Mr. Shah, even at 7:30 a.m.

headline: Fred Siegel, Urban Historian and a Former Liberal, Is Dead at 78
abstract: His books traced his ideological transformation from a Democratic Socialist in New York to neoconservative partisan for Rudolph Giuliani and Donald Trump.
paragraph: Fred Siegel, a passionate urban historian whose rejection of the liberal establishment’s response to crime, poverty and public civility transformed him from a spokesman for the Democratic presidential nominee George McGovern in 1972 to a voter for Donald J. Trump in 2020, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 78.

headline: Ecuador Strikes a Landmark Deal to Protect the Galápagos, and Save Cash
abstract: A creative debt restructuring will save the country money and create a fund to protect waters around the Galápagos Islands.
paragraph: Ecuador announced a record-setting deal on Tuesday designed to reduce its debt burden and free up hundreds of millions of dollars to fund marine conservation around the Galápagos Islands, an archipelago of unique biodiversity that’s famous for inspiring Darwin’s theory of evolution.

headline: He Could Uncork Trillions to Help Fix the Planet
abstract: What steps will Ajay Banga take when he becomes World Bank chief? We asked an expert on the bank’s climate affairs.
paragraph: What if a new world leader came on the scene who could potentially free up trillions to help developing countries cope with climate change?

headline: Apple Weather Fails Again, and Users Scramble
abstract: Yet another app failure was a reminder of how dependent we’ve become on our phones to tell us when the sun is shining. Here are some options if it happens again.
paragraph: iPhone users trying to plan what to wear around the weather on Tuesday might have had some difficulty if they were relying solely on Apple’s weather app.

headline: Price to Plug Old Wells in Gulf of Mexico? $30 Billion, Study Says.
abstract: There are roughly 14,000 old, unplugged wells in the gulf that are at risk of springing leaks or causing environmental damage, researchers found.
paragraph: Ever since the first offshore platforms went up off Louisiana 85 years ago, the Gulf of Mexico has been an oil and gas juggernaut. But decades of drilling has left behind more than 14,000 old, unplugged wells at risk of springing dangerous leaks and spills that may cost more than $30 billion to plug, a new study has found. Nonproducing wells that haven’t been plugged now outnumber active wells in the gulf, the study says.

headline: Wildfires Burn Nearly 1 Million Acres in Western Canada
abstract: Light rain and cooler temperatures brought much-needed relief over the weekend to Alberta, where nearly 30,000 residents have been forced to evacuate.
paragraph: A shift in weather conditions brought much-needed relief to firefighters in Western Canada, where around 964,000 acres have burned since wildfires started more than a week ago, destroying dozens of structures and forcing nearly 30,000 residents of Alberta to evacuate.

headline: Climate Change Powered the Mediterranean’s Unusual Heat Wave
abstract: Last week, it felt more like July or August in Spain, Portugal and North Africa, and global warming was most likely to blame, scientists say.
paragraph: The early-season heat wave that broiled parts of Algeria, Morocco, Portugal and Spain last week almost certainly would not have occurred without human-induced climate change, an international team of scientists said in an analysis issued Friday.

headline: Backup Power: A Growing Need, if You Can Afford It
abstract: Extreme weather linked to climate change is causing more blackouts. But generators and batteries are still out of reach for many.
paragraph: When frigid weather caused rolling blackouts on Christmas Eve across North Carolina, Eliana and David Mundula quickly grew worried about their 2½-week-old daughter, whom they had brought home days earlier from a neonatal intensive care unit.

headline: Sick of Bumpy, Delayed Flights? New Weather Tech Could Help.
abstract: A.I. and innovations like hyperlocal radar stations and a constellation of future satellites may soon improve forecasts and smooth out your journeys.
paragraph: It may be a tough summer to fly. More passengers than ever will be taking to the skies, according to the Transportation Security Administration. And the weather so far this year hasn’t exactly been cooperating.

headline: Oil Executive Who Heads U.N. Climate Talks Hints at His Approach
abstract: In a speech, Sultan al-Jaber, the Emirati official presiding over this year’s climate summit, spoke of emissions cuts, but experts also cited ambiguity in his statements.
paragraph: Scientists and activists have long argued at global climate summits that the only way to slow down global warming is to eliminate its main driver, fossil fuel production.

headline: The ‘Devil Bird’ Lands in New York, With More Likely to Come
abstract: Anhingas, water birds with snakelike necks, have turned up in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and far upstate, a sign of shifting ranges for birds from the South.
paragraph: For two weeks, a strange bird has perched in Brooklyn over the treetops of one of the Three Sisters Islands in Prospect Park Lake. It shows no signs of heading back to the place it most likely came from in the South.

headline: Living and Breathing on the Front Line of a Toxic Chemical Zone
abstract: As the Biden administration moves to curb health threats caused by toxic chemicals, the debate hits home for families living near petrochemical plants.
paragraph: Juan López had just returned home from his job supervising the cleaning of giant tanks that hold toxic chemicals produced along the Houston Ship Channel, one of the largest petrochemical complexes in the world.

headline: An Irish Abbey Where the Grass Is Always Warmer
abstract: The sisters at St. Mary’s Abbey in Ireland grow their own heating fuel.
paragraph: Between Holy Week and the demands of farm life, it wasn’t easy to get Sister Lily Scullion on the phone in April. (“Sorry for the delay, have been very busy with lambing,” she wrote in an email.)

headline: Danish Wind Pioneer Keeps Battling Climate Change
abstract: Henrik Stiesdal helped design the first modern wind turbines. A thousand patents later, he’s a green tech entrepreneur rolling out new innovations.
paragraph: The contemporary wind power industry, which has spawned hundreds of thousands of spinning rotors generating electricity without putting greenhouse gases into the air, was to a great extent born in a notoriously windy region of Denmark called Jutland.

headline: Ideas, and Coffee, Robust Enough for the Climate Crisis
abstract: On a recent reporting trip, your Climate Forward host met small farmers adapting to climate hazards in all kinds of creative ways.
paragraph: As a climate journalist, I get asked a perennial question by my fellow Americans: What do I do in the face of a crisis so big and complicated?

headline: A Chill Hotel in Every Way But One
abstract: The architect of the beachfront Hotel Terrestre, in Mexico, refused to incorporate air-conditioning.
paragraph: When representatives of Grupo Habita asked the architect Alberto Kalach to design an earth-friendly, energy-efficient hotel along the jungle coast of Oaxaca, he knew he would need a few things in return.

headline: United Auto Workers Hold Off on Backing Biden, for Now
abstract: A memo by the union’s president underscores how some of President Biden’s moves to fight climate change could weaken some of his political support.
paragraph: The United Auto Workers, a politically potent labor union, is planning to withhold its endorsement of President Biden in the early stages of the 2024 race, according to an internal memo from its president to members on Tuesday.

headline: A House That Is as Green as It Gets
abstract: A down-to-earth couple in California asked for a structure that was guaranteed to be net-zero energy.
paragraph: Eleven years ago, Sally Liu, a water-resources engineer, and her husband Bay Chang, then a senior research scientist for Google, bought a 0.84-acre lot for $2.675 million in suburban Hillsborough, Calif. Avid environmentalists in their mid-40s with two young sons, they set out to build something different from the neighborhood’s overblown mansions and closer to their hearts: a green energy home.

headline: ‘A New Spike’ in Global Temperatures in the Forecast
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization reports increased odds that El Niño, the global weather pattern often tied to intense heat, will arrive by fall.
paragraph: Forecasters from the World Meteorological Organization are reporting increased chances that the global climate pattern known as El Niño will arrive by the end of summer. With it comes increased chances for hotter-than-normal temperatures in 2024.

headline: An Architect Known for Building Castles in the ‘Vegetable Kingdom’
abstract: A man of many hats, Emilio Ambasz practiced green architecture long before it was fashionable.
paragraph: When the architect Emilio Ambasz won a 1998 competition to redesign the headquarters of Eni S.p.A., an oil company controlled by the Italian government, he recalled wagging a metaphorical finger at the company’s president, saying: “You owe it to Italy to do something green.”

headline: Is It a Lake, or a Battery? A New Kind of Hydropower Is Spreading Fast.
abstract: So-called pumped storage, rather than conventional dams, is emerging as the future of deriving electricity from water's gravitational qualities.
paragraph: So-called pumped storage, rather than conventional dams, is emerging as the future of deriving electricity from water's gravitational qualities.

headline: Looking for a Climate Career? They Might Have the Answer.
abstract: For this month’s Someone to Know profile, we spoke to M.B.A. students who help their peers track down climate-focused jobs.
paragraph: Newly minted Stanford business school grads can count on making around $175,000 a year when they graduate. Usually, that means a job in private equity, consulting or Big Tech.

headline: What Climate Change Could Mean for the Coffee You Drink
abstract: As global warming threatens the two main varieties, coffee growers in Uganda are betting on a type that can stand up to heat, drought and pests.
paragraph: First the bad news. The two types of coffee that most of us drink — Arabica and robusta — are at grave risk in the era of climate change.

headline: Meet the Climate Hackers of Malawi
abstract: On tiny farms they’re testing creative ideas to stay ahead of the cascading threats — heat and drought, cyclones and floods — transforming their world.
paragraph: When it comes to growing food, some of the smallest farmers in the world are becoming some of the most creative farmers in the world. Like Judith Harry and her neighbors, they are sowing pigeon peas to shade their soils from a hotter, more scorching sun. They are planting vetiver grass to keep floodwaters at bay.

headline: Climate Change Made East Africa’s Drought 100 Times as Likely, Study Says
abstract: The findings starkly show the misery that the burning of fossil fuels, mostly by rich countries, inflicts on societies that emit almost nothing by comparison.
paragraph: Two and a half years of meager rain have shriveled crops, killed livestock and brought the Horn of Africa, one of the world’s poorest regions, to famine’s brink. Millions of people have faced food and water shortages. Hundreds of thousands have fled their homes, seeking relief. A below-normal forecast for the current rainy season means the suffering could continue.

headline: Exxon and Chevron Report More Modest Profits as Oil and Gas Prices Ease
abstract: The oil industry enjoyed record profits in 2022 after Russia invaded Ukraine, but the prices of oil and natural gas have fallen sharply in recent months.
paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest American oil companies, reported relatively modest earnings growth on Friday as they were forced to manage their businesses in the face of sagging prices for oil and natural gas.

headline: Spain Bakes in Summer-Like Heat, and Worries About What Comes Next
abstract: The April temperatures, over 100 degrees Fahrenheit in some places, come on top of a long-running drought that has depleted reservoirs and dried up fields.
paragraph: In Madrid, where it hit around 90 degrees Fahrenheit on Friday, schools were allowed to close early to avoid the heat. In Catalonia, it’s so dry that the valves of an irrigation canal have been closed for lack of water. And in Seville, the police are investigating the death of a horse pulling a tourist carriage from apparent heatstroke.

headline: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
abstract: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s plan to limit, for the first time, greenhouse gas emissions from existing power plants could hinge on the ability of plant operators to capture carbon dioxide before it is pumped into the atmosphere.

headline: Here Are the Places Most at Risk From Record-Shattering Heat
abstract: It’s the regions of the world that haven’t yet experienced an off-the-charts heat wave that we should worry about, a new scientific study argues.
paragraph: Global warming is making dangerously hot weather more common, and more extreme, on every continent. A new study by researchers in Britain takes a unique approach to identifying which places are most at risk.

headline: A New Tax on Greenhouse Gases
abstract: In a first, the European Union is imposing a charge on some high-emissions imports like steel. Here’s what it means.
paragraph: The European Union has approved the world’s first carbon tax on imports. It’s designed to make certain products a lot more expensive if they come from manufacturers that aren’t paying for their greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Many Young Voters Bitter Over Biden’s Support of Willow Oil Drilling
abstract: Despite his aggressive moves to try to slash greenhouse gas emissions, President Biden has angered young climate voters upset by a drilling project in Alaska.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the past three weeks, President Biden’s administration has proposed regulations to speed the transition to electric vehicles, committed $1 billion to help poor countries fight climate change and prepared what could be the first limits on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants.

headline: Leonardo’s Ferry Left High and Dry by Global Warming and Red Tape
abstract: A ferry used to traverse the banks of the Adda River, in northern Italy, but drought and an abundance of bureaucracy have closed it down.
paragraph: On a recent sunny morning on the banks of the Adda River in northern Italy, schoolchildren on a class trip to Imbersago — the “Town of the Ferry of Leonardo da Vinci” — gathered next to a moored boat and listened as a guide explained how the flights of the river’s birds, the formations of its rocks and the workings of its ships inspired Leonardo’s genius.

headline: Roll the Dice, Save Gotham From Climate Catastrophe!
abstract: A board game challenges players to decarbonize New York City, and energy experts are paying attention.
paragraph: At a training facility for Consolidated Edison workers in Queens, there is a yard with electric poles where line workers can master climbing skills, a replica of the city’s underground electric structures for practice fixing wires, and a library where employees can play the climate change board game Energetic.

headline: E.P.A. to Propose First Controls on Greenhouse Gases From Power Plants
abstract: If the regulation is implemented, it will be the first time the federal government has limited carbon emissions from existing power plants, which generate 25 percent of U.S. greenhouse gases.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s administration is poised to announce limits on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants that could compel them to capture the pollution from their smokestacks, technology now used by fewer than 10 of the nation’s 3,400 coal and gas-fired plants, according to three people who were briefed on the rule.

headline: 7 Inspiring Reads for Earth Day
abstract: We picked some of our favorite articles from the Times’s Climate Desk.
paragraph: For the past 53 years, April 22 has been Earth Day. It started as a call for a regeneration of a polluted environment and has since come to focus on climate change.

headline: Overlooked No More: Elizabeth Wagner Reed, Who Resurrected Legacies of Women in Science
abstract: Reed made several discoveries in genetics and dedicated her career toward supporting women scientists. Yet she herself fell into obscurity.
paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Canada Lands Volkswagen Battery Plant With Billions in Subsidies
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the assistance was needed to offset incentives offered by the United States.
paragraph: Volkswagen’s first North American battery plant for electric vehicles will be built in Canada, and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and other Canadian politicians made it clear on Friday that the country had effectively been in a bidding war with the United States.

headline: Why Solving Climate Change Is Not an Issue Where We ‘Succeed or Fail’
abstract: A climate reporter explains the findings of a distressing report and why the crisis never really fades from the news cycle, even if it seems otherwise.
paragraph: The window to prevent the catastrophic effects of climate change is rapidly closing.

headline: Go Green, Then ‘Go Dark’?
abstract: Some companies are keeping quiet about their sustainability initiatives, aiming to shield themselves from blowback from the right and the left.
paragraph: Some companies are keeping quiet about their sustainability initiatives, aiming to shield themselves from blowback from the right and the left.

headline: The Giving Forest
abstract: The Menominee tribe has sustainably logged its forest in Wisconsin for 160 years. But that careful balance faces a crisis: too many trees and too few loggers.
paragraph: MENOMINEE COUNTY, Wis. — Amid the sprawling farmlands of northeast Wisconsin, the Menominee forest feels like an elixir, and a marvel. Its trees press in, towering and close, softening the air, a dense emerald wilderness that’s home to wolves, bears, otters, warblers and hawks, and that shows little hint of human hands.

headline: Biden to Create White House Office of Environmental Justice
abstract: A new executive order requires every federal agency to address the disproportionate impact of pollution and climate change on minority communities.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday announced the creation of a White House Office of Environmental Justice, one of several actions to address the unequal burden that people of color carry from environmental hazards.

headline: Nurturing Nature in Your Yard
abstract: A reader wanted to attract pollinators and foster biodiversity without spending a bundle to redo her property. We’ve got tips.
paragraph: Gabrielle Stevenson needed advice on how to welcome pollinators and other wildlife to her front yard in Roseville, Calif. She knew that replacing part of her lawn with native plants was the best way to nurture biodiversity there. But she didn’t want a mess and didn’t know where to begin.

headline: NOAA Forecasters See a Respite for California
abstract: Less extreme spring temperatures could mean gradual snowmelt and lower flood risks, according to experts. “The picture is relatively optimistic,” one said.
paragraph: Weather forecasters with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on Thursday issued their latest outlook for the United States, and there’s at least one piece of hopeful news for a state that has already had a wild year, weather-wise: California.

headline: Biden Pledges $500 Million to Stop Deforestation in Brazil
abstract: The promise to help Brazil protect the Amazon must be approved by Congress, where Republicans are opposed to foreign climate aid.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday pledged $500 million to fight deforestation in Brazil and more than $1 billion to help developing countries transition away from fossil fuels and become more resilient to the impacts from climate change.

headline: Seaweed Is Having Its Moment in the Sun
abstract: Seaweed is being reimagined as a plastic substitute, even as cattle feed. But can it thrive in a warming world?
paragraph: Seaweed is being reimagined as a plastic substitute, even as cattle feed. But can it thrive in a warming world?

headline: Electric Vehicle Tax Credit Rules Create ‘Chaos for Consumers’
abstract: Buying an electric car has become much more complicated because of restrictions on which models qualify for a federal tax credit of up to $7,500.
paragraph: Designed to accelerate the shift to electric cars among other climate goals, the Inflation Reduction Act has in practice made buying such vehicles a lot more complicated.

headline: Tesla’s Profit Dropped Sharply in First Quarter as It Cut Prices
abstract: The electric carmaker has reduced prices by thousands of dollars this year to bolster demand and fend off competition.
paragraph: Tesla’s profit fell sharply in the first three months of the year after it cut the prices of its electric vehicles, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Those Seaweed Blobs Headed for Florida? See How Big They Are.
abstract: The amount of Sargassum drifting toward North America is a record for the month of March.
paragraph: The amount of Sargassum drifting toward North America is a record for the month of March.

headline: Coping With Extreme Heat
abstract: A disaster in India highlights the health hazards of being out under a hot sun.
paragraph: Extreme heat can be deceptively dangerous, even in places accustomed to extreme heat. India learned that lesson in a deadly episode over the weekend.

headline: Texas to New Jersey: Tracking the Toxic Chemicals in the Ohio Train Inferno
abstract: Tankers of vinyl chloride were going halfway across the country, government records show, a trip highlighting the risks of transporting chemicals as plastics production grows.
paragraph: When a freight train carrying more than 100,000 gallons of hazardous chemicals derailed and burned in East Palestine, Ohio, this year, it set off a panic over rail safety and the toxic fallout for communities downwind.

headline: U.S. Car Brands Will Benefit Most From Electric Car Tax Breaks
abstract: Rules that take effect on Tuesday will limit the $7,500 credits to electric cars made domestically with minerals from the U.S. or trade allies.
paragraph: American brands like Tesla and General Motors will benefit most from rules that determine which electric vehicles qualify for tax credits starting on Tuesday. Foreign carmakers like Hyundai will be at a significant disadvantage because of restrictions aimed at cutting China out of the supply chain.

headline: How Electrifying Everything Became a Key Climate Solution
abstract: To tackle climate change, we’ll need to plug in millions of cars, trucks, home heaters, stoves and factories.
paragraph: To tackle climate change, we’ll need to plug in millions of cars, trucks, home heaters, stoves and factories.

headline: Building Better Buildings
abstract: Homes and offices have huge climate footprints. There are many ways to fix that.
paragraph: Here’s something we know we have to fix, and we mostly know how to fix it.

headline: After She Traded One Patagonia for Another, Tragedy Couldn’t Keep Her Away
abstract: The documentary “Wild Life” tells the story of Kristine Tompkins, a former chief executive who retired at 43 and moved to South America for love and conservation.
paragraph: SANTA PAULA, Calif. — Kristine McDivitt Tompkins’s idea of sibling bonding is a monthlong trip to Antarctica on an icebreaker ship, including an icy dunk into the frigid waters of the Ross Sea, kayaking, hikes on icebergs and a lot of time analyzing maps.

headline: As World Warms, Droughts Come On Faster, Study Finds
abstract: When rains fail unexpectedly, higher temperatures can more rapidly parch the ground, to devastating effect.
paragraph: Flash droughts, the kind that arrive quickly and can lay waste to crops in a matter of weeks, are becoming more common and faster to develop around the world, and human-caused climate change is a major reason, a new scientific study has found.

headline: Biden Plans an Electric Vehicle Revolution. Now, the Hard Part.
abstract: The administration’s push to supercharge E.V. sales must now surmount resistance from manufacturers and consumers as well as likely legal challenges.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aggressive rules proposed by the Biden administration to drastically speed up the country’s transition to electric vehicles, and significantly cut the auto pollution that is dangerously heating the planet, face several economic, logistical and legal challenges.

headline: Inspired by Jane Goodall, Onscreen and in Real Life
abstract: “Jane,” a new Apple TV+ series, tries to deliver Goodall’s environmental message through a young protagonist with insatiable curiosity.
paragraph: Jane Goodall is not a fan of television. In her limited free time, this renowned British primatologist and environmentalist may occasionally watch a wildlife documentary by her friend David Attenborough, or, after a hard day, “something mindless,” as she said in a recent video interview.

headline: Confused About Electric Cars? We Have Some Answers.
abstract: Here is what car buyers need to know about the Biden administration’s proposal to push the auto industry to sell more electric cars.
paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday proposed ambitious auto emissions rules that could significantly change the kinds of cars and trucks on sale in the United States — but not right away.

headline: E.P.A. Lays Out Rules to Turbocharge Sales of Electric Cars and Trucks
abstract: The Biden administration is proposing rules to ensure that two-thirds of new cars and a quarter of new heavy trucks sold in the United States by 2032 are all-electric.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday proposed the nation’s most ambitious climate regulations to date, two plans designed to ensure two-thirds of new passenger cars and a quarter of new heavy trucks sold in the United States are all-electric by 2032.

headline: Why the West Got Buried in Snow, While the East Got Little
abstract: This winter was starkly different on each coast. These maps show just how much.
paragraph: This winter was starkly different on each coast. These maps show just how much.

headline: Biden Administration Proposes Evenly Cutting Water Allotments From Colorado River
abstract: As the river shrinks, the Biden administration is getting ready to impose, for the first time, reductions in water supplies to states.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of fruitless negotiations between the states that depend on the shrinking Colorado River, the Biden administration on Tuesday proposed to put aside legal precedent and save what’s left of the river by evenly cutting water allotments, reducing the water delivered to California, Arizona and Nevada by as much as one-quarter.

headline: Why Are Taxpayers Propping Up the Fossil Fuel Industry?
abstract: Worldwide, government subsidies for oil and gas are at a record high. Global financial institutions have been trying for years to get them phased out.
paragraph: Here’s a huge climate challenge that you don’t hear much about: Around the world, taxpayers are helping to support fossil fuels through subsidies when their money could be funding green energy transitions instead.

headline: Automakers Face Test in Reaching U.S. Target for Electric Vehicles
abstract: New federal rules are expected to speed the transition to E.V.s, a shift that car companies have embraced but will be challenged to carry out.
paragraph: The Biden administration’s plan to accelerate the adoption of electric vehicles — reaching a two-thirds share of new cars in less than a decade — pushes automakers further in a direction they have already been going. But meeting the new timetable will be a challenge.

headline: The World Bank Is Getting a New Chief. Will He Pivot Toward Climate Action?
abstract: Under pressure from world leaders, development experts and shareholders, the bank opens its spring meeting on Monday, poised for big changes.
paragraph: As World Bank shareholders gather in Washington for their annual spring meeting on Monday, the global institution appears to be on the brink of significant change.

headline: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
abstract: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.
paragraph: Texas was gasping for electricity. Winter Storm Uri had knocked out power plants across the state, leaving tens of thousands of homes in icy darkness. By the end of Feb. 14, 2021, nearly 40 people had died, some from the freezing cold.

headline: Can Climate Change Make for Good TV?
abstract: ‘Extrapolations’ on Apple TV+ is one of a few ambitious shows about climate change. We asked the Times’s chief TV critic what works and what doesn’t when dramatizing global warming.
paragraph: Films and TV shows may be powerful tools to raise awareness about climate change. But, as we discussed in a previous newsletter, they’ve been put to that use only rarely.

headline: E.P.A. Is Said to Propose Rules Meant to Drive Up Electric Car Sales Tenfold
abstract: In what would be the nation’s most ambitious climate regulation, the proposal is designed to ensure that electric cars make up the majority of new U.S. auto sales by 2032.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is planning some of the most stringent auto pollution limits in the world, designed to ensure that all-electric cars make up as much as 67 percent of new passenger vehicles sold in the country by 2032, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Calculating the Fastest Road to an Electric Car Future
abstract: Government scientists have spent a year analyzing electric vehicles to help the E.P.A. design new tailpipe rules to trigger an electric car revolution.
paragraph: Inside a secretive government laboratory, behind a tall fence and armed guards, a team of engineers has been dissecting the innards of the newest all-electric vehicles with a singular goal: Rewrite tailpipe pollution rules to speed up the nation’s transition to electric cars.

headline: New Support for Some Extinct Tasmanian Tiger Sightings
abstract: The last thylacine died in captivity in 1936, but a statistical analysis adds a degree of validity to the survival of small groups of the carnivorous marsupials.
paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, the Tasmanian tiger or thylacine has either been extinct for nearly a century or has been just really good at hiding.

headline: Biden Administration to Curb Toxic Pollutants From Chemical Plants
abstract: The rule would chiefly affect plants along the Gulf Coast, the Ohio River Valley and in West Virginia.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday proposed a new regulation to significantly reduce hazardous air pollutants from chemical plants, a move that environmental advocates predicted would significantly reduce the health risks to  people living near industrial sites.

headline: It’s Not Just Willow: Oil and Gas Projects Are Back in a Big Way
abstract: Alaska’s controversial Willow project has drawn criticism, but a global analysis shows that it’s just one of hundreds of investments approved in the past year or so.
paragraph: When the Biden administration greenlighted the enormous $8 billion Willow oil project on Alaska’s North Slope last month, many decried the move as a betrayal of the United States’ pledge to move away from fossil fuels in the fight against climate change.

headline: In Pristine Alaska, an Oil Giant Prepares to Drill for Decades
abstract: Scientists say nations must stop new oil and gas projects to avoid climate catastrophe. But after the Biden administration greenlit the $8 billion Willow project, ConocoPhillips is racing ahead.
