paragraph: MIAMI — For much of Game 3 of the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference finals on Sunday, Jimmy Butler did something he does not often do: He played a supporting role. He created off the dribble, zipped passes to his Heat teammates for open shots and pushed to score only when the opportunity made too much sense not to seize it.

headline: Welcome to the Era of W.N.B.A. Superteams. New Stars Need Not Apply.
abstract: The Liberty have a stacked roster and championship ambitions. But where are all the rookies?
paragraph: The Liberty began their much hyped season as the newest superteam on the block, winning their home opener against the Indiana Fever, 90- 73.

headline: First Came the Sports Betting Boom. Now Comes the Backlash.
abstract: In many U.S. states and across the world, regulators are cracking down on the sports gambling industry, citing harm to the public and, in some cases, to athletes.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — Legislators and regulators who began the headlong expansion of legalized gambling in the United States are now moving in spots nationwide to tighten oversight of the gambling industry, particularly as it relates to advertising that may reach underage bettors.

headline: Why did Forte’s positive test take so long to come out?
abstract: Forte tested positive for meloxicam in September. He then won four races, including the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile, and was named the 2-year-old male champion. So why did the result not become public until May?
paragraph: Three days after a Kentucky Derby in which five horses were scratched, including the morning-line favorite Forte, The New York Times reported that Forte had failed a drug test after winning the Hopeful Stakes on Sept. 5. Two days after that report, Forte was disqualified from the Hopeful and his trainer, Todd Pletcher, was suspended for 10 days and fined $1,000.

headline: The Not-So-Genteel Side of Tennis Is in the College Playoffs
abstract: The N.C.A.A. championships bring a brand of tennis that is not for the faint of heart. This year it’s all going down in steamy Orlando.
paragraph: It took roughly an hour for the last rounds of the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s tennis championships to get real.

headline: What to Know About the 2023 W.N.B.A. Season
abstract: New superteams, new rules and Brittney Griner’s return are reshaping the league as star rookies try to make their mark.
paragraph: The W.N.B.A. begins its 27th season on Friday with new rules, new rosters and one big return. Here’s what to expect.

headline: Nadal to Miss French Open for the First Time in 19 Years
abstract: Rafael Nadal has been suffering from an injury to his lower abdomen and right leg since the Australian Open in January.
paragraph: Rafael Nadal has been suffering from an injury to his lower abdomen and right leg since the Australian Open in January.

headline: The Heat’s Secret Weapon? Players Who Were Snubbed on Draft Night.
abstract: The Miami Heat have nine undrafted players — more than any other N.B.A. team. “When you’re in that position,” one player said, “you’re willing to do anything.”
paragraph: BOSTON — Max Strus had spent two seasons punishing defenders as a shooting guard at Lewis University, a Division II school in Romeoville, Ill., before he delivered some news to his coach that was not entirely unexpected: He wanted to transfer to a major Division I program.

headline: Rafael Nadal Withdraws From the French Open, Wants to Play One More Year
abstract: Nadal, the Spanish star, has battled a core muscle injury since January. He said that next season “probably is going to be my last year in the professional tour.”
paragraph: Rafael Nadal, the 14-time French Open men’s singles champion, will not compete in this year’s edition of the event that has defined his career because of an injury that has sidelined him for months.

headline: After a ‘Kill Shot’ to the Eye, a Wrestler Restarts His Life
abstract: Rich Perry was an Olympic hopeful when he sustained a gruesome injury at a training camp in 2018. The question now is whether he can ever fully be himself again.
paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It was a small moment that would have been unremarkable before Richard Perry’s traumatic brain injury, a wrestling coach staying after practice to speak with a younger wrestler, playfully clutching him, making a razzing joke.

headline: An N.F.L. Doctor Wants to Know Why Some Players Get C.T.E. and Others Don’t
abstract: The newly opened National Sports Brain Bank plans to study head trauma specific to athletes. Jerome Bettis has already pledged to donate his brain.
paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Joseph Maroon, a neurosurgeon, began working for the Pittsburgh Steelers as a consulting doctor starting in 1977 and over 46 years has examined and treated stars from the notoriously hard-nosed dynasty, including the Hall of Famers Terry Bradshaw, Mean Joe Greene and Lynn Swann.

headline: How Victor Wembanyama Could Fit on the San Antonio Spurs
abstract: The Spurs know a thing or two about developing talented big men. But the once-stable franchise hasn’t been good for years.
paragraph: Victor Wembanyama, the 7-foot-4 dynamic forward who is this year’s most prized N.B.A. prospect, cheered with his family in France as the San Antonio Spurs won the 2023 draft lottery Tuesday night. In San Antonio, fans, perhaps understandably, celebrated like they had won a championship, yelling in bars and honking car horns.

headline: The Liberty Took a Few Jets and a Boat to Become a Superteam
abstract: Clara Wu Tsai and Joe Tsai, the Liberty owners, improved their facilities and chartered flights, drawing a W.N.B.A. fine — and enticing top free agents.
paragraph: In January, Clara Wu Tsai flew to Turkey on a trip that altered the balance of power in the W.N.B.A.

headline: Tennis Elbow Is a Real Pain. Here’s How to Treat It.
abstract: The painful condition isn’t just caused by racket swings, and can sideline you from activity. But a few simple tips can get you back into the game.
paragraph: Now that warm weather is here to stay, many Americans are getting back into their favorite outdoor sports and starting home projects. Which means, among other things, the annual uptick in tennis elbow.

headline: San Antonio Spurs Get the No. 1 Pick in the N.B.A. Draft Lottery
abstract: The top pick is widely expected to be Victor Wembanyama, a 19-year-old French basketball star.
paragraph: The San Antonio Spurs won the 2023 N.B.A. draft lottery on Tuesday, giving them the No. 1 pick in June’s draft and the right to select the most anticipated prospect since LeBron James: the 19-year-old French star Victor Wembanyama.

headline: Aces Coach Becky Hammon Suspended 2 Games for Pregnancy Comments
abstract: The All-Star forward Dearica Hamby had accused an unnamed person of making “disgusting comments” and questioning her commitment to the team after she became pregnant.
paragraph: The W.N.B.A. on Tuesday suspended Las Vegas Aces Coach Becky Hammon for two games for comments she made to the All-Star forward Dearica Hamby about her pregnancy. While the players’ union said the punishment did not go far enough, the Aces defended Hammon as a “caring human.”

headline: What to Know About the N.B.A. Draft Lottery
abstract: A draw on Tuesday in Chicago will determine the order for the first 14 picks in the 2023 draft, which will be held in June.
paragraph: Fans of the N.B.A. are about to take a break from praying that a wild, off-balance 3-pointer goes in and instead turn to praying that a particular envelope happens to contain the logo of their favorite team.

headline: Everybody Wants Victor Wembanyama. He Wants to Rule the N.B.A.
abstract: The 19-year-old French basketball star is the most hyped N.B.A. prospect since LeBron James, but he says he isn’t fazed by the pressure.
paragraph: Boris Diaw was passing through Paris in late September and thought he would check out a basketball game. A young player he had heard about for years was playing.

headline: Don Denkinger, 86, Top Umpire Remembered for Botched Call, Dies
abstract: His reputation as a lauded, longtime major-league umpire was overshadowed by a pivotal wrong call he made during the 1985 World Series.
paragraph: Don Denkinger was regarded as one of the finest major-league umpires of his time. Working in the American League from 1969 to 1998, he was assigned to four World Series and three All-Star Games.

headline: Tori Bowie’s Hometown Celebrates Her Life Amid Mystery of Her Death
abstract: Mourners at a visitation and funeral in Mississippi remembered Tori Bowie as an inspiration on the track while also searching for answers about how her life ended.
paragraph: BRANDON, Miss. — Before she became a three-time Olympic medalist and before she earned the title of world’s fastest woman, Frentorish Bowie welcomed a camera crew to her hometown, Sandhill, Miss.

headline: Joe Kapp’s Lawsuit Paved the Way for N.F.L. Free Agency
abstract: The Vikings and Patriots quarterback successfully challenged pro football’s standard contracts in the 1970s, setting a legal precedent that the players’ union used to win later court battles.
paragraph: It was one of the more surreal contract negotiations in N.F.L. history. At the start of training camp in July 1971, Joe Kapp, the New England Patriots’ star quarterback, was locked in an office with Upton Bell, the team’s new general manager, and Billy Sullivan, its principal owner.

headline: Trainer of Onetime Derby Favorite Is Disciplined in Doping Case
abstract: Forte, the Kentucky Derby favorite until he was scratched with an injury, failed a drug test last September. His trainer, Todd Pletcher, received a 10-day suspension and a $1,000 fine.
paragraph: New York regulators on Thursday suspended the Hall of Fame trainer Todd Pletcher for 10 days, fined him $1,000 and disqualified his colt Forte — the favorite in last week’s Kentucky Derby until he was scratched because of an injury — as the winner of a stakes race last September in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

headline: Forte, Once the Derby Favorite, Failed a Drug Test in September
abstract: The colt went on to become America’s 2-year-old champion and was favored to win the Kentucky Derby until he was scratched from the race with an injury. The doping case still hasn’t been adjudicated.
paragraph: After a disquieting period in which seven horses died at Churchill Downs during the run-up to last week’s Kentucky Derby, horse racing is again caught up in a controversy, this one a doping case involving one of its biggest stars.

headline: An N.F.L. Star Finds Confidence in Making Music
abstract: The tight end Darren Waller called music his “best tool of expression,” one he pursued in a busy off-season that saw him traded to the Giants and marry a W.N.B.A. champion.
paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — About 30 minutes into Darren Waller’s recording session, a music producer asked him to make a small tweak.

headline: A Tennis Match That’s Also a College Program’s Farewell
abstract: The men’s tennis team at St. Francis of Brooklyn just finished its best season with a trip to the N.C.A.A. tournament. Soon, the college will have no sports programs at all.
paragraph: On an overcast day, before a few dozen people at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, a team of players wearing light blue uniforms battles a team in dark blue across six courts.

headline: Indian Olympians Persist in Demanding Arrest of Wrestling Chief
abstract: Athletes vow to continue a protest after a clash with the police, saying politicians are covering for an official accused of sexually harassing female wrestlers.
paragraph: A group of India’s most accomplished wrestlers, who have accused the sport’s top official in the country of serial harassment and abuse of female wrestlers, vowed on Friday to continue a day-and-night protest after a clash two days before with the Delhi police.

headline: Derby Entrant Is Scratched as Four Horse Deaths Renew Safety Concerns
abstract: In the past week, two horses died after sustaining injuries and two horses conditioned by the same trainer collapsed and died at Churchill Downs, prompting an investigation.
paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two days before horse racing’s signature event, the Kentucky Derby, Kentucky racing officials on Thursday threw a horse out of the race under a cloud of suspicion after two of his trainer’s horses collapsed and died without explanation in the past week.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: The N.F.L. draft continues, while the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs will wrap up.
paragraph: The N.F.L. draft continues, while the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs will wrap up.

headline: A Triathlon Champion’s Positive Test Jolts the Sport, Creating a Soap Opera
abstract: Collin Chartier tested positive for erythropoietin, the well-known illegal stamina enhancer. It came as a shock to devotees of one of the ultimate endurance pursuits, where stamina is everything.
paragraph: For the small, insular world of triathlon, it has been a week.

headline: Who Won, and Who Lost, in the 2023 N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Philadelphia, Detroit and Green Bay all had their reasons for making the picks they did. Here’s what we learned in the draft aftermath.
paragraph: The Philadelphia Eagles’ general manager, Howie Roseman, hustled like a pool shark. The Detroit Lions’ coach, Dan Campbell, displayed his rugged individualism. And the Green Bay Packers, playing the role of a merry divorcé post-Aaron Rodgers trade, dallied with new playmakers.

headline: Jets and Giants Focus on Defense in Round 1 of the N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Though prognosticators guessed that both teams might look for offensive players, the Jets chose an edge rusher from Iowa State and the Giants selected a Maryland cornerback.
paragraph: The New York area’s football teams, at least moderately successful last year, did not get to pick in the glamorous top few spots in the first round of the N.F.L. draft on Thursday. Away from the spotlight, they both selected defensive players who look like they can help already solid cores.

headline: What We Learned From Round 1 of the N.F.L. Draft
abstract: The Carolina Panthers surprised no one by selecting Bryce Young of Alabama. The Houston Texans began building their future. And a highly regarded quarterback wasn’t chosen at all.
paragraph: After months of workouts, measurements, interviews, speculation, prognostication and whispers about players rising and falling for inscrutable reasons, the top of the first round of the N.F.L. draft on Thursday night went roughly the way experts thought it would go at the end of the last college football season.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Picks 2023: All the Results From the First Round
abstract: The Carolina Panthers selected Bryce Young, the Alabama quarterback, at No. 1 overall. Other teams shook up the top 10 with trades. Here’s a full list of the results from the first round on Thursday.
paragraph: 1. Carolina Panthers (via trade)Bryce Young, QB, Alabama

headline: John Underwood, Stylish Sportswriter and Author, Dies at 88
abstract: After fishing with Ted Williams in 1967, he collaborated with him on two books. He also helped the Alabama football coach Bear Bryant write his autobiography.
paragraph: John Underwood, a stylish writer at Sports Illustrated for nearly a quarter century, whose rollicking account of a fishing trip in Florida with the baseball Hall of Famer Ted Williams led to their collaborations on two highly regarded books, died on April 12 at his home in Miami. He was 88.

headline: Why the N.F.L. Draft Is About Much More Than Football
abstract: It’s an awards presentation, a Hallmark Channel-style TV drama, a beauty pageant and a reality show. And the N.F.L. really knows how to sell.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: Their Reputations Precede Them. And That’s the Problem.
abstract: When an athlete breaks the rules of the game, he or she may be judged on much more than that single act. Call it the Draymond Green Effect.
paragraph: Most times in basketball, a foul is just a foul. But sometimes, it can feel like so much more: a Rorschach test unearthing a person’s biases about the game, a window into a player’s thinking, a referendum on his entire career.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: What to Know
abstract: Who will be taken at No. 1 overall? Which teams will come out ahead? And, in a 32-team league, why are there only 31 picks in the first round?
paragraph: College football stars will take their first steps toward becoming professional football stars (or flops) at the 2023 N.F.L. draft. Expect to hear “Alabama,” “Georgia” and “Ohio State” a lot, as well as “acceleration,” “physicality” and “football I.Q.”

headline: On His First Day as a Jet, Rodgers Says the Team Can Win It All
abstract: “I really try and listen to the signs and synchronicities that the universe puts in our face every day,” Aaron Rodgers said, “and this was basically the direction that everything was pointing.”
paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Aaron Rodgers walked into the Jets’ facility on Wednesday for his introductory news conference to applause from staffers after they watched a montage of his highlights from his 18-year tenure with the Green Bay Packers.

headline: Will Georgia’s Jalen Carter Still Be a Top N.F.L. Draft Pick?
abstract: After pleading no contest to two misdemeanor charges for his role in a fatal car crash, the defensive lineman has become one of the most inscrutable prospects in Thursday’s draft.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: Transfer Portal Shows the Latest Revolving Door in College Football
abstract: Colorado has numerous scholarships available after a change in its coaching staff, serving as one of many examples of how the transfer portal has created a market similar to professional free agency.
paragraph: When the curtain went up on Saturday, light snowflakes were coming down on the University of Colorado football team’s spring game.

headline: Anthony Richardson’s N.F.L. Draft Status Is Up in the Air
abstract: A quarterback, Richardson has a knack for high-flying plays, but he posted an uneven season at Florida. He has spent the past five months working to convince N.F.L. executives that he is a first-round pick.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: The Yoga Regimen That Keeps an N.B.A. Forward Centered
abstract: Everyone wants an edge during the N.B.A. playoffs. Some like naps. Some have lucky shoes. Golden State’s Kevon Looney does “Joga.”
paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Early Sunday morning, Kevon Looney of the Golden State Warriors decamped to a quiet atrium on the fourth floor of Chase Center, where floor-to-ceiling windows offered an expansive view of San Francisco Bay. The sun was beginning to burn through a hazy sky as Looney propped his iPad against a small metal column, unrolled his black yoga mat and greeted one of the more important figures in his professional life.

headline: After Focusing on Tragedy, the N.F.L. Draft Looks to Change Its Tone
abstract: Criticism of the fascination with players’ bodies and the focus on tragic family histories has the league and its broadcast partners rethinking the draft.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: With Jets Trade, Aaron Rodgers Gets His Ask: A Team Desperate for Him
abstract: Rodgers, a four-time league M.V.P. with the Green Bay Packers, will look to turn the Jets into a Super Bowl contender.
paragraph: The Green Bay Packers traded quarterback Aaron Rodgers to the Jets on Monday, ending a three-year power struggle between the Packers and one of pro football’s greatest passers.

headline: House Passes Bill to Bar Transgender Athletes From Female Sports Teams
abstract: The bill, championed by Republican lawmakers, has no chance of passing the Democratic-controlled Senate or being signed by President Biden.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Thursday approved legislation that would bar transgender women and girls from participating in athletic programs designated for women, part of a nationwide push by conservatives to restrict transgender rights as they make culture issues a centerpiece of their political message.

headline: When a Los Angeles Playoff Game Ends, Their Jobs Begin
abstract: Between Thursday and Monday night, Crypto.com Arena will have hosted four N.B.A. games and two in the N.H.L. It was an eventful weekend for the workers who convert the venue from rink to court.
paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jorge Mendez waited impatiently as the Los Angeles Kings’ fate hung in the balance late Friday night.

headline: Davis vs. Garcia: A Marquee Fight That Is Actually Happening
abstract: When Gervonta Davis and Ryan Garcia square off Saturday night, they’ll satisfy boxing fans who are often left disappointed by fight negotiations that go nowhere.
paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When Gervonta Davis and Ryan Garcia stood face to face, posing for the photos that closed out their news conference on Thursday, another argument erupted between the two boxers.

headline: Gervonta Davis Wants to Be Known for More Than His Knockouts
abstract: Davis, who goes by Tank, said he wants to be a star, “the whole package.” For now he is known for decisive victories in the ring and dubious decisions outside of it.
paragraph: The scene was a cross between a hip-hop concert and the Met Gala as Gervonta Davis sauntered toward the boxing ring for his 2019 fight against Yuriorkis Gamboa.

headline: Rafael Nadal May Miss the French Open
abstract: The so-called King of Clay continues to battle the injury he suffered in January at the Australian Open, the latest in a string of ailments to have plagued the twilight of his career.
paragraph: Hopes for Rafael Nadal to compete for a 15th French Open singles title this spring took a major hit on Thursday.

headline: Mets Aces Battle With Batters, Umpires, Injuries and Time
abstract: Max Scherzer was ejected from Wednesday’s win over the Los Angeles Dodgers because of a foreign substance, providing yet another speed bump for the Mets’ starting rotation.
paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Starting pitchers for 200. It was not a Jeopardy question at Dodger Stadium this week. It was a prelude-to-Cooperstown and anticipating-the-stretch-run kind of number.

headline: Damar Hamlin Is Cleared to Return to Football
abstract: The Buffalo Bills safety, who went into cardiac arrest during an N.F.L. game in January, is “in a great head space to come back and make his return,” according to the team’s general manager.
paragraph: Damar Hamlin, the Buffalo Bills safety whose heart stopped during a prime time game in January, has been cleared to return to football activities, Bills General Manager Brandon Beane announced Tuesday.

headline: N.B.A. Suspends Miles Bridges for 30 Games for Domestic Violence
abstract: Bridges pleaded no contest to felony domestic violence in November. He was accused of assaulting the mother of his children.
paragraph: Miles Bridges, the N.B.A. forward who pleaded no contest to felony domestic violence in the fall, has been suspended for 30 games, the league announced on Friday. Bridges, 25, had played for the Charlotte Hornets for four seasons before he was accused of assaulting his girlfriend in front of their children last June. He was not under contract during the 2022-23 regular season and did not appear in any games.

headline: N.F.L. Draft 2023: The Trends That Will Shake Up the Top Picks
abstract: The success of Air Raid offenses, changes to college football rules and athletic defenses will impact the players selected when the draft begins April 27.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: N.B.A. Blames Economy for Hiring Freeze and Budget Cuts
abstract: In a memo, the league said it was “facing a very different economic reality than just one year ago.”
paragraph: The N.B.A., citing “economic headwinds,” instructed league office staff on Tuesday to reduce expenses and significantly limit hiring for the rest of the fiscal year, according to a memo obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Even in Exile, Bob Baffert Is the King of the Sport of Kings
abstract: Baffert was barred from Triple Crown races after Medina Spirit tested positive for a prohibited drug at the 2021 Kentucky Derby. But owners keep sending him expensive horses — and he keeps winning.
paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif.— As exiles go, Bob Baffert’s has been a comfortable one. Most mornings, the horse trainer who is barred from competing in the Kentucky Derby, can be found beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains, holding court at Clockers’ Corner, the open-air bistro at Santa Anita Park.

headline: W.N.B.A. Draft: Aliyah Boston Goes No. 1 to Indiana Fever
abstract: Boston, a senior forward from the University of South Carolina, was the second-ever top pick from her college.
paragraph: When Aliyah Boston was 12 years old, she took a 1,700-mile journey with her sister to their aunt’s home in Massachusetts from the U.S. Virgin Islands, hoping to become a good enough basketball player to go to college for free and maybe one day make it to the W.N.B.A.

headline: A Growing W.N.B.A. Still Boxes Out Some Personalities
abstract: Ahead of the W.N.B.A. draft, women’s basketball remains troubled by racial disparities in how its stars are showcased.
paragraph: Aliyah Boston, one of the most dominant and decorated players in women’s college basketball, was selected with the top pick in the W.N.B.A. draft Monday night.

headline: Fans of Women’s Sports Walk Into a Bar Inspired by Women’s Sports
abstract: The Sports Bra in Portland, Ore., is a rarity dedicated exclusively to women’s sports. The latest highlight was the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball final.

headline: Hobie Landrith, the First New York Met, Dies at 93
abstract: A major league catcher for 14 seasons, he was the first player picked by the newly formed Mets in the expansion draft in 1961.
paragraph: Hobie Landrith caught for seven teams in his 14 major league seasons. He was mostly a backup, good enough at handling pitchers but a light hitter. He was never an All-Star. But he did possess a modest claim to fame.

headline: At the Masters, Brooks Koepka Holds the Lead and Tiger Woods Withdraws
abstract: Woods exited the tournament during the third round that finished around noon on Sunday. Koepka held a two-stroke lead over Jon Rahm head into the final round.
paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods withdrew on Sunday from the Masters Tournament, where he was in last place and openly struggling to overcome the agony of years of injuries.

headline: Supreme Court Rules for Transgender Girl in School Sports Dispute
abstract: The justices issued a temporary order allowing the girl to compete on the girls’ track team at a West Virginia middle school.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that a transgender girl may compete on the girls’ cross country and track teams at her middle school in West Virginia while her appeal moved forward, signaling that a majority of the justices are not ready to enter another battleground in the culture wars.

headline: Biden Plan Allows Limits on Trans Athletes’ Participation in School Sports
abstract: It is the first time the administration has substantively weighed in on the charged debate. The proposal would also prevent schools from enacting across-the-board bans.
paragraph: The Biden administration proposed a rule change on Thursday that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities. But the proposal would also prevent schools from enacting across-the-board bans.

headline: U.S. Women Lose Mallory Swanson in World Cup Tuneup
abstract: Swanson was carted off with a serious knee injury during a 2-0 victory over Ireland, a blow to the United States’ hopes of winning a third consecutive World Cup championship.
paragraph: UPDATE: U.S. Soccer announced on Sunday that Mallory Swanson had torn the patella tendon in her left knee late in the first half of Saturday’s game against Ireland. The injury usually requires months of recovery, most likely ruling out Swanson for Women’s World Cup that begins in July.

headline: The Runners Changing Course on Uniform Expectations
abstract: In competitive running, norms dictating attire are sticky but changing.
paragraph: In eighth grade, Katelyn Hutchinson, a runner from the University of Kentucky, learned the power of a uniform.

headline: Biden Plan for Transgender Title IX Rules Began on Inauguration Day
abstract: Officials were working on a plan to protect transgender athletes since the day the president was sworn in. In recent months, they raced to issue protections as states moved to revoke them.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Biden signed an executive order in his first hours in office to strengthen prohibitions against gender and sexual discrimination, a small team of officials in the Department of Education began assessing an unanswered but important question: How could the administration protect transgender athletes?

headline: Title IX and the New Rule on Transgender Athletes Explained
abstract: The Biden administration proposed a rule change that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities.
paragraph: The Biden administration on April 6 released long-awaited draft rules regarding the participation of transgender athletes in school sports, taking its first official stand on a matter that has become a contentious public debate. The rule would have broad implications for the ability of athletes from elementary school T-ball to the N.C.A.A. level to play.

headline: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Shatters Ratings Record in Final
abstract: The average 9.9 million viewers for Louisiana State topping Iowa was significantly more than the previous record of 5.7 million for an N.C.A.A. women’s tournament game, achieved in 2002 when Connecticut won the title.
paragraph: The gritty battle for the women’s college basketball championship on Sunday between Louisiana State and Iowa drew an average of 9.9 million viewers, making it the most viewed N.C.A.A. women’s basketball final in television history, ESPN said on Monday. Peak viewership hovered around 12.6 million views and overall viewership was about double the viewership of the championship game last year.

headline: San Diego State’s Deep Run Plays Right Into Conference Realignment
abstract: San Diego State had set itself up for this moment. Not just for a run at a championship, but for jumping to a bigger conference.
paragraph: HOUSTON — Whether or not John David Wicker, the San Diego State athletic director, owns many leather-bound books or an apartment that smells of rich mahogany, he could be pardoned for channeling his inner Ron Burgundy.

headline: The Endorsement Deals Shaping the N.C.A.A. Tournaments
abstract: Both Miami’s men’s and women’s teams made deep runs in March. Their athletes also had significant backing in the form of name, image and likeness deals.
paragraph: DALLAS — Last spring, Isaiah Wong led the University of Miami’s men’s basketball team to its best season to that point, a run to the round of 8 in the N.C.A.A. tournament, where it lost to Kansas, the eventual champion.

headline: Iowa’s Win Over South Carolina Was a Hit for ESPN, With 5.5 Million Viewers
abstract: The highly anticipated matchup delivered more viewers than any non-championship game in women’s college basketball. And the Iowa-Louisiana State final on Sunday is on network TV.
paragraph: The nail-biting victory for Caitlin Clark and Iowa over South Carolina on Friday night in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament semifinal was watched by an average of 5.5 million viewers, ESPN said on Saturday, citing early data from Nielsen. That is the third-largest audience ever on ESPN for a women’s college basketball game, and the largest audience ever for a semifinal.

headline: As the Final Four Finishes, a Parallel Transfer Season Plays Out, Too
abstract: Call it the consolation bracket, as teams jockey for position for next season.
paragraph: HOUSTON — It wasn’t long before Kansas and North Carolina tipped off for the men’s college basketball championship in New Orleans last April that Darrion Trammell called San Diego State Coach Brian Dutcher with some news. He wanted to join the Aztecs.

headline: The Way You Watch Sports on TV Is Changing. Here’s Why.
abstract: The slow collapse of regional sports networks that broadcast baseball, basketball and hockey games has implications for viewers and for the sports themselves.
paragraph: The system of regional sports network television channels — which televise most Major League Baseball, N.B.A. and N.H.L. games and pay billions of dollars to teams each season — is slowly collapsing, and the way consumers watch sports on TV is changing.

headline: When Every Win Means Water, Water Everywhere
abstract: Hold the champagne. Water has become the go-to beverage for celebrating success in sports.
paragraph: Hold the champagne. Water has become the go-to beverage for celebrating success in sports.

headline: It’s a Really Weird Time to Be an Umpire
abstract: With replay cameras watching every call, it has become an increasingly stressful job — and baseball’s new rules will just make it harder.
paragraph: Remember that scene in “The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!” when Lt. Frank Drebin disguises himself as the home-plate umpire at a California Angels game to stop the future Hall of Fame slugger Reggie Jackson from assassinating the queen of England? If you haven’t seen the movie, just go with it. With every strike that Drebin calls, he gets increasingly drunk on the cheers from the home crowd. He pirouettes on Strike 2. He barks out “Steeeee-rike three” before the ball even crosses the plate, then fires his finger guns, does the moonwalk and pulls some moves like Jagger. The batter is not amused. His manager and his teammates in the dugout are not amused. Ricardo Montalban and Priscilla Presley, sitting in the front row of the stands, are not amused.

headline: Facing Criticism, a Gambling Company and a University End Their Deal
abstract: The decision by PointsBet and University of Colorado Boulder came as the industry released guidelines meant to limit how sports betting is marketed on campus.
paragraph: With lawmakers and educators pressuring gambling companies and universities over deals they have made to promote sports betting on campuses, one of the most noteworthy and heavily criticized partnerships was disbanded Wednesday.

headline: Thanks to Their Versatility, the Mets Are Feeling Good
abstract: Edwin Díaz’s injury would crush some teams, but the Mets, with a deep and experienced roster, have remained optimistic.
paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It is one of baseball’s enduring little mysteries, how a game so rich in possibilities also offers so many precedents. You may see something new at the ballpark every day, yet if you stick around a while, you feel like you’ve seen it all before.

headline: Senator Seeks Details of Schools’ Deals With Betting Companies
abstract: Senator Richard Blumenthal, asserting that gambling causes “very real harm” to students, has asked 66 colleges to provide information about their marketing relationships with sportsbooks.
paragraph: Pressure is continuing to build upon colleges and universities that have partnerships with sports betting companies.

headline: The Income Gap Is Becoming a Physical-Activity Divide
abstract: Nationwide, poor children and adolescents are participating far less in sports and fitness activities than their more affluent peers.
paragraph: Over the last two decades, technology companies and policymakers warned of a “digital divide” in which poor children could fall behind their more affluent peers without equal access to technology. Today, with widespread internet access and smartphone ownership, the gap has narrowed sharply.

headline: Ja Morant Moves Toward ‘Redemption’ After Gun Video
abstract: Back from an eight-game suspension, the Memphis Grizzlies guard said he had more work to do to improve himself. But there was also a hint of defiance in his approach.
paragraph: MEMPHIS — When Ja Morant checked into his first game in almost three weeks on Wednesday, Grizzlies fans at the FedEx Forum wrapped him in the warm embrace of a standing ovation and prolonged roars.

headline: N.F.L. Teams Are Bullish on Cornerbacks and Bearish on Running Backs
abstract: Recent off-season deals also show that trades are hot, free-agent signings are not, and “bridge quarterback” is one of the greatest jobs ever.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: N.B.A. ‘Bad Boy’ Wants Players to Do as He Says, Not as His Teams Did
abstract: Joe Dumars was on the 1980s Detroit Pistons teams known for their hard fouls. But players and coaches who step out of line today can expect fines and suspensions — from him.
paragraph: Joe Dumars chuckled at his desk in Midtown Manhattan as framed portraits of links to the N.B.A.’s past — Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain and Gus Williams — loomed behind him.

headline: Today’s Top News: The PGA Tour’s Shock Merger With LIV Golf, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
paragraph: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.

headline: At 81, Martha Stewart Is the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue Cover Star
abstract: The domestic diva talks about shedding her inhibitions, and (most of) her clothes, for the cover shoot.
paragraph: It’s useless to try to pigeonhole Martha Stewart. Decorously entertaining homemaker-slash-lifestyle guru, television personality, publisher, canny entrepreneur-turned-white-collar criminal, Snoop Dogg’s unlikely BFF — these are labels she spins, or drops when it suits her, as adroitly as a juggler.

headline: Leaders Let Problems Mount at Brutal SEAL Course, Navy Finds
abstract: Overzealous instructors, unchecked drug use, and inadequate leadership and medical oversight turned a tough selection course into a dangerous ordeal, investigators found.
paragraph: The notoriously grueling Navy SEAL selection course grew so tough in recent years that to attempt it became dangerous, even deadly. With little oversight, instructors pushed their classes to exhaustion. Students began dropping out in large numbers, or turning to illegal drugs to try to keep up.

headline: George Washington University Drops Colonial Moniker
abstract: The move comes after criticism of the team’s nickname because of its association with violence toward Native Americans and other colonized people.
paragraph: George Washington University announced a new name — Revolutionaries — for its athletic teams on Wednesday, after years of pressure from students who said the previous moniker, “Colonials,” glorified violence toward Native Americans and other colonized people.

headline: How New Rules Turned Back the Clock on Baseball
abstract: Visualizing the effect of changes two months into the season.
paragraph: Visualizing the effect of changes two months into the season.

headline: Adventure and Independence Await. Bug Spray Sold Separately.
abstract: Seven brand-new and time-tested books about sleepaway camp.
paragraph: Ghost stories and s’mores. Friendship bracelets and three-legged races. Trail mix, canoe trips, stars visible from a cozy bunk. For some kids who’ve been lucky enough to belt out “99 Bottles of Beer on the Wall” on a bus bound for the middle of nowhere, these are the touchstones of a place that becomes the center of everything — a backdrop for little lessons and big mileposts, a haven to return to year after year. For others, sleepaway camp is a hellscape of mystery meat, mean counselors, itchy sunburn, belly flops and kickballs to the gut. Their letters are desperate pleas for compassionate release, with nary a mention of the stained glass workshop or floating trampoline that made the program attractive to begin with.

headline: Fairleigh Dickinson, Princeton, Furman and the Joy of March Upsets
abstract: “This is one of the few things in life where they told me how good it was and, somehow, it’s better.”
paragraph: SACRAMENTO — At its best, March isn’t about madness so much as pure, unbridled joy.

headline: Who Is Fairleigh Dickinson, the No. 16 Seed That Beat Purdue?
abstract: The Knights, who delivered one of the biggest upsets in March Madness history by defeating Purdue, made an unlikely run just to even get to the game.
paragraph: The men’s basketball team at Fairleigh Dickinson University, a private commuter school with a campus in Teaneck, N.J., went 4-22 last season. Three of its best players and its coach were competing in Division II. And the Knights, playing in the Northeast Conference, didn’t even win their conference tournament, a title they normally would have needed to make the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Georgia’s Jalen Carter Avoids Jail Time for Role in Fatal Crash
abstract: Carter, projected as a top-five pick in the N.F.L. draft, pleaded no contest to two misdemeanor charges and will serve 12 months of probation.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: Mets Closer Will Miss Season After Injury During Celebration
abstract: Edwin Díaz collapsed after closing out Puerto Rico’s win over the Dominican Republic in the World Baseball Classic. Recovery from knee surgery will take eight months.
paragraph: MIAMI — A rousing 5-2 victory by Puerto Rico over the Dominican Republic on Wednesday earned the team a spot in the quarterfinals of the World Baseball Classic. But the elation quickly turned into despair when the star closer Edwin Díaz crumbled to the ground during a postgame celebration on the mound.

headline: A Shooting That Ensnared Alabama Players Could Have Been Deadlier
abstract: Surveillance video from a deadly January shooting shows that a basketball player and his passenger were in a car struck by bullets. Neither was hurt.
paragraph: Editors’ Note, June 2, 2023

headline: Top N.B.A. Prospects Skip College, but Not Stardom
abstract: The N.B.A.’s biggest stars often make their names during the N.C.A.A. tournament. But this year’s top draft picks may be players who found the spotlight elsewhere.
paragraph: As children, the twin brothers Amen and Ausar Thompson adopted their father’s favorite sports teams. That made them Cleveland Cavaliers fans, then Miami Heat fans, then Cavs fans again as they followed LeBron James’s journey through the N.B.A. But when it came to men’s college basketball, there was no wandering around. They rooted for Kentucky.

headline: Why the Horse Racing Beat Goes On
abstract: Joe Drape, The Times’s “turf writer,” is just as entranced by horse racing as his predecessors were.
paragraph: Joe Drape’s colleagues at The New York Times know where he’ll be every first Saturday in May: at Churchill Downs in Louisville to report on the Kentucky Derby. Mr. Drape, a reporter and editor on the Sports desk, has covered the Triple Crown of horse racing for The Times since 1998. He covers many topics, including football, the gambling industry and e-sports. But it’s his position as a “turf writer” — a term for journalists who cover horse racing — at a national news organization that stands out.

headline: Pro Golfers Are Hitting Balls Way Too Far. Some Say It Has to Stop.
abstract: Driving distance has been steadily increasing, and a proposal on Tuesday by the U.S. Golf Association and the R&A could affect elite players within three years.
paragraph: MARANA, Ariz. — Elite golfers, who have increasingly used head-turning distances on their drives to conquer courses, should be forced to start using new balls within three years, the sport’s top regulators said Tuesday, inflaming a debate that has gathered force in recent decades.

headline: Once Underdogs, They’re Still Playing With Chips on Their Shoulders
abstract: No. 2-seed Marquette was picked ninth of 11 teams in the Big East preseason poll. The Golden Eagles’ point guard, Tyler Kolek, hasn’t forgotten.
paragraph: Near the start of the college basketball season, a reporter told Marquette point guard Tyler Kolek that the Golden Eagles had been picked to finish ninth out of 11 teams in the Big East Conference.

headline: 2023 N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Bracket
abstract: Sixty-eight teams will take their shot at the national championship. See the bracket here.
paragraph: Sixty-eight teams will take their shot at the national championship. See the bracket here.

headline: South Carolina Tops N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Field
abstract: There are challengers, of course, but no team is tougher on paper than the undefeated, reigning champion Gamecocks.
paragraph: When the 68-team field for the N.C.A.A. Division I women’s basketball tournament was announced on Sunday night, the least surprising selection was the No. 1 overall seed: South Carolina. The Gamecocks, who are also the reigning champion, will anchor a portion of the bracket that has its regional in nearby Greenville, S.C.

headline: 2023 N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Bracket
abstract: Follow the latest scores and bracket updates as the tournament unfolds.
paragraph: Follow the latest scores and bracket updates as the tournament unfolds.

headline: Pat McCormick, Olympic Diving Champion, Is Dead at 92
abstract: The first diver to sweep the gold medals in two Olympics, she won numerous national championships in a career that ended when she was still in her 20s.
paragraph: Pat McCormick, the first diver to sweep the gold medals in two Olympics, died on Tuesday at an assisted living facility in Santa Ana, Calif. She was 92.

headline: House Votes to Block Transgender Athletes From Female Sports Teams
abstract: The Republican-backed bill would prohibit athletes who have transitioned from male to female from competing in women’s sports.
paragraph: The Republican-backed bill would prohibit athletes who have transitioned from male to female from competing in women’s sports.

headline: Electric Vehicle Tax Credit Rules Create ‘Chaos for Consumers’
abstract: Buying an electric car has become much more complicated because of restrictions on which models qualify for a federal tax credit of up to $7,500.
paragraph: Designed to accelerate the shift to electric cars among other climate goals, the Inflation Reduction Act has in practice made buying such vehicles a lot more complicated.

headline: Giants Commit to Daniel Jones With a Four-Year Contract
abstract: Jones, 25, had sought a major raise after leading the Giants to the playoffs in the last year of his rookie deal.
paragraph: The Giants and quarterback Daniel Jones agreed to a four-year contract extension with $82 million in guaranteed money, securing his role as the franchise’s starter after months of negotiations.

headline: Is Arthritis Avoidable?
abstract: Joint pain, stiffness and swelling aren’t always inevitable results of aging, experts say. Here’s what you can do to reduce your risk.
paragraph: Q: What can we do to avoid getting arthritis as we age?

headline: North Dakota Bars Trans Girls and Women From Female Sports Teams
abstract: The governor signed the laws late Tuesday night, part of a package of anti-trans legislation heading to his desk.
paragraph: North Dakota on Tuesday night became the latest state to bar transgender girls and women from joining female sports teams, starting from kindergarten and all the way through college.

headline: Televised Face Slapping? What Are We Becoming?
abstract: Slap fighting competitions have drawn the support of Dana White and Arnold Schwarzenegger, along with national TV audiences. But, our columnist writes, the so-called sport is indefensible.
paragraph: What’s next, who can survive being run over by a tank?

headline: How a Campaign Against Transgender Rights Mobilized Conservatives
abstract: Defeated on same-sex marriage, the religious right went searching for an issue that would re-energize supporters and donors. The campaign that followed has stunned political leaders across the spectrum.
paragraph: When the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage nearly eight years ago, social conservatives were set adrift.

headline: An Ordinary Player Who’s Anything But
abstract: Hansel Enmanuel, who lost his left arm at age 6, doesn’t want sympathy. He just wants to play.
paragraph: NATCHITOCHES, La. — Hansel Enmanuel knew just what to do when his teammate DeMarcus Sharp was marooned in the lane after picking up his dribble, surrounded by defenders. Enmanuel bolted from the corner toward the basket.

headline: China’s Car Buyers Have Fallen Out of Love With Foreign Brands
abstract: Domestic companies are now selling more vehicles than their multinational rivals, which have failed to keep up with Chinese consumers’ demand for electric cars and S.U.V.s.
paragraph: For years, foreign automakers in China had a bead on customers drawn to luxury brands, like the Cao family in Shanghai. Not anymore.

headline: Time Is No Longer on Their Side
abstract: Fans are eager to start the pitch-clock era, but baseball’s pitching coaches are hard at work trying to adjust to one of the biggest changes in M.L.B. history.
paragraph: For the past 150 years, baseball has sold the timeless nature of the sport. How long will today’s game take? However long it takes. But recently, the caretakers of the sport at its highest level — Major League Baseball — have seemed to fret that their game might need saving.

headline: The Steak House With N.F.L. Deals on the Menu
abstract: When the N.F.L.’s power brokers meet at St. Elmo Steak House in Indianapolis, trades, contracts and shrimp cocktail are all on the table.
paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 N.F.L. draft.

headline: E.P.A. Lays Out Rules to Turbocharge Sales of Electric Cars and Trucks
abstract: The Biden administration is proposing rules to ensure that two-thirds of new cars and a quarter of new heavy trucks sold in the United States by 2032 are all-electric.
paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday proposed the nation’s most ambitious climate regulations to date, two plans designed to ensure two-thirds of new passenger cars and a quarter of new heavy trucks sold in the United States are all-electric by 2032.

headline: Can Patrick Kane Lift the Rangers as the N.H.L. Playoffs Loom?
abstract: The three-time Stanley Cup winner with Chicago desperately wanted a trade to New York. He got his wish, and will be tested Saturday when the Rangers play the Bruins, the N.H.L.’s top team.
paragraph: The most stirring moments for Patrick Kane came in the pregame warm-up and player introductions, which is an indication of how things went on his first night playing for the Rangers. Kane skated onto the ice at Madison Square Garden about a half-hour before the opening face-off on Thursday, and fans greeted him with a standing ovation, holding up signs of appreciation and cheering his every move until he skated off.

headline: Black Equestrians Want to Be Safe. But They Can’t Find Helmets.
abstract: For Black riders with natural hair, finding a helmet that fits can be virtually impossible. Some are trying to raise awareness of the problem, but manufacturers say it’s not a simple fix.
paragraph: Chanel Robbins has been riding horses most of her life, ever since her grandmother traded a cow from their family’s farm in Ontario for a pony when she was 7.

headline: He Was Billed as the Next LeBron. But Will Emoni Bates Make It at All?
abstract: Bates was on a magazine cover at 15. He was playing Division I college basketball at 17. Now he’s 19, his college career may be over, and N.B.A. success is anything but guaranteed.
paragraph: YPSILANTI, Mich. — From time to time, Emoni Bates shows flashes of the player he was supposed to be. Like the moment in a recent game when he received the ball near the 3-point arc and took a couple of hard dribbles toward the basket, a 6-foot-10 bundle of kinetic energy, his spindly arms and legs flailing in rhythm with his bobbing, bundled-up hair.

headline: The French Sports Minister’s Trials by Fire
abstract: Amélie Oudéa-Castéra’s first year in office brought chaos at the Champions League final and scandals in soccer and rugby. With the Paris Olympics looming, her toughest days may be ahead.
paragraph: UPDATE: The longtime president of the French soccer federation, Noël Le Graët, resigned on Tuesday.

headline: Vanessa Bryant Settles Helicopter Crash Photos Lawsuit for $28.85 Million
abstract: Bryant, the widow of the basketball star Kobe Bryant, sued Los Angeles County after some of its employees shared graphic photos of the crash that killed her husband and one of their daughters.
paragraph: Los Angeles County agreed to pay Vanessa Bryant and three of her daughters nearly $30 million to settle a lawsuit and potential claims over the sharing of graphic photos of the January 2020 helicopter crash that killed Bryant’s husband, the basketball star Kobe Bryant, and one of their daughters, according to a court filing on Tuesday. The settlement includes $15 million a jury awarded Vanessa Bryant in August, with additional funds to settle potential claims from her daughters.

headline: Jacob deGrom Liked the Mets. But the Rangers Liked Him More.
abstract: Texas was desperate for pitching and deGrom’s interest was piqued. A $185 million contract and a “vision” of how to win persuaded him to leave New York.
paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Watching from afar while he played for the Mets, Jacob deGrom said he had his eye on the Texas Rangers. He did not get to see them play often, but definitely noticed when they doled out $581 million in contracts before the 2022 season to a group of free agents headlined by the All-Star infielders Corey Seager and Marcus Semien.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: It's finally time for the N.B.A. and N.H.L. finals, and college softball takes the stage.
paragraph: It's finally time for the N.B.A. and N.H.L. finals, and college softball takes the stage.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: The Indy 500 and Monaco Grand Prix will excite racing fans, while European soccer clubs will face their big moments.
paragraph: The Indy 500 and Monaco Grand Prix will excite racing fans, while European soccer clubs will face their big moments.

headline: How a Trade Changed Everything for Two N.B.A. Players and Their Dogs
abstract: Professional sports can be a tough business. When Mikal Bridges was dealt from the Suns to the Nets, his friend Cam Payne had to give the news to Sonny and Uno.
paragraph: When Mikal Bridges was traded from the Phoenix Suns to the Nets in early February, he had to join his new team without stopping at home in Arizona first.

headline: Saudi Arabia Relishes a Triumph That Transcends Sports
abstract: The deal to merge LIV Golf with the PGA Tour is a big win for the oil-rich kingdom, headlining a banner week that also includes a visit from the American secretary of state.
paragraph: When a Saudi-backed upstart golf league began recruiting high-profile players from the top U.S. circuit, the American tour’s commissioner lamented a “foreign monarchy that is spending billions of dollars in an attempt to buy the game of golf.”

headline: Karim Benzema Joins Al-Ittihad, Becoming Latest Saudi Sports Prize
abstract: The acquisition of Benzema is part of a billion-dollar project to lure global stars to Saudi Arabia’s top league and expand the kingdom’s sports profile.
paragraph: Karim Benzema, one of soccer’s best players and a fixture at the Spanish giant Real Madrid for more than a decade, has agreed to join the Saudi champion Al-Ittihad on a three-year contract that will make him the latest prize acquisition for a kingdom rapidly expanding its ambitions and influence in sports.

headline: What Would Happen if Women Athletes Got the Mythology Treatment They Deserve?
abstract: Time, instead of adding to the luster of women’s sports as it does men’s, erodes it.
paragraph: The photograph of Muhammad Ali flexing over a fallen Sonny Liston is one of the most famous in sports history. The moment, and the image, are iconic, sold in every format imaginable, while also helping mythologize an athlete, a sport and even an era.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Brittney Griner’s return to the W.N.B.A., the Preakness Stakes, the P.G.A. Championship and more.
paragraph: Brittney Griner’s return to the W.N.B.A., the Preakness Stakes, the P.G.A. Championship and more.

headline: Endeavor and W.W.E. Said to Be Close to Deal Combining Fighting Leagues
abstract: A union of Endeavor’s U.F.C. combat league and World Wrestling Entertainment would increase the combined company’s leverage in negotiations with content distributors.
paragraph: Endeavor, the Hollywood entertainment colossus that owns the Ultimate Fighting Championship, is close to a deal that would combine that league with World Wrestling Entertainment, two people familiar with the negotiations said on Sunday. The combination would establish a behemoth in combat entertainment, both real and scripted.

headline: An Unlikely Champion
abstract: The publisher of The New York Times received a Red Sox World Series ring after Boston’s historic triumph in 2004.
paragraph: Even today, Boston Red Sox fans would recognize the names inscribed on the bejeweled 2004 World Series rings: Damon. Francona. Martínez. Ortiz. Ramirez. Schilling. Sulzberger. Varitek.

headline: LIV Golf Wants to Talk About Sports. Donald Trump Still Looms.
abstract: Whether LIV can outrun Trump’s shadow, and whether it even wants to, could do much to shape how the league is perceived in the years ahead, particularly in the United States.
paragraph: It was only on Sunday evening that LIV Golf, the men’s league awash in billions of dollars from Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, met its greatest athletic triumph to date when one of its headliners, Brooks Koepka, emphatically won the P.G.A. Championship.

headline: With a Quick Violation, M.L.B.’s Pitch Clock Era Begins
abstract: Manny Machado was issued a strike for not being ready in the batter’s box as baseball got its first look at a sped-up game.
paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — In the first inning of a spring training game against the Seattle Mariners here on Friday, San Diego Padres third baseman Manny Machado placed his left foot in the batter’s box, tapped his bat on home plate and twirled it around before coming set. It is a routine he has done countless times.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Premier League soccer teams will fight to avoid relegation, while the X.F.L. will crown a champion.
paragraph: Premier League soccer teams will fight to avoid relegation, while the X.F.L. will crown a champion.

headline: A Common Sight on U.S. Campuses: The Rest of the World’s Female Olympians
abstract: A federal law opened doors for millions of American women. It also made the United States an incubator for women’s national teams worldwide.
paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Sini Karjalainen could have played ice hockey closer to home.

headline: ‘Imagining the Indian’ Review: Fighting Offensive Imagery
abstract: This documentary, subtitled “The Fight Against Native American Mascoting,” argues that Native-themed sports team branding fits into a history of systemic racism.
paragraph: In July 2020, the National Football League team in Washington announced that it would shed a name that was long considered a slur against Indigenous people. The decision was a victory in the campaign by Native American activists to eliminate disparaging sports team names and iconography.

headline: LIV Golf Joins a Club That Will Have It as a Member
abstract: The PGA Tour’s merger with LIV is the perfect union of the tour’s lack of principle and LIV’s paucity of character.
paragraph: They said it was about principles, but it was always about money.

headline: What Tour Leaders and Players are Saying About the Merger
abstract: Players and officials are split on the a blockbuster agreement.
paragraph: PGA Tour officials and LIV leaders hailed the announcement on Tuesday that their competing golf series would be joining forces, but players were split on the news. Here’s what they were saying:

headline: PGA Tour and LIV Golf Agree to Alliance, Ending Golf’s Bitter Fight
abstract: In a stunning announcement, the tour, along with the DP World Tour and Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, said the rivals had agreed to create a “new, collectively owned, for-profit entity.”
paragraph: The PGA Tour, the dominant force in men’s professional golf for generations, and LIV Golf, which made its debut just last year and is backed by hundreds of millions of dollars in Saudi money, will together form an industry powerhouse that is expected to transform the sport, executives announced Tuesday.

headline: Trump Praises the PGA and LIV Golf Merger
abstract: The LIV series has been a boon for the Trump family, which lost major tournaments after the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the capitol.
paragraph: The Trump family, which has been the host of LIV tournaments in the United States and a big booster of the series’ efforts to break away from the PGA Tour, expects to continue to see tournaments played at its golf courses once the merger is complete.

headline: In Reprieve for PGA Tour, Rory McIlroy Backs Saudi Deal
abstract: McIlroy, however, reiterated his lingering opposition to LIV Golf, saying: “I still hate LIV. I hate them. I hope it goes away.”
paragraph: The PGA Tour, facing a crush of internal dissent for its choice this week to accept the kind of Saudi money it spent the last year denouncing as tainted, appeared Wednesday to have the support of one of its most powerful players: Rory McIlroy, who had been one of the foremost critics of the Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit, which had convulsed the sport.

headline: Canvas of Clay
abstract: The iconic courts at Roland Garros can tell the tale of a match if you look closely enough.
paragraph: The iconic courts at Roland Garros can tell the tale of a match if you look closely enough.

headline: Jim Hines, First to Sprint 100 Meters in Under 10 Seconds, Dies at 76
abstract: He ran a gold-medal-winning time of 9.95 seconds at the Mexico City Olympics in 1968, setting an official world record that held for 15 years.
paragraph: Jim Hines, who in 1968 became the first man to sprint 100 meters in under 10 seconds, and later that year won a gold medal in that distance at the Olympic Games in Mexico City with a blistering time of 9.95 seconds, a mark that stood as a world record for 15 years, died on Saturday in Hayward, Calif. He was 76.

headline: The Merger of LIV Golf and the PGA Tour: Here’s What to Know
abstract: The announced deal to dramatically change golf is far from complete.
paragraph: The PGA Tour, the world’s pre-eminent professional golf league, and LIV Golf, a Saudi-funded upstart whose emergence over the past year and a half has cleaved the sport in two, have agreed to join forces.

headline: Through Ties to Saudis, Golf Deal Promises Benefits to Trump
abstract: The new alliance between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf is the latest example of how the former president’s relationship with Saudi Arabia has yielded gains, and criticism, for both.
paragraph: The surprising deal on Tuesday ending a civil war in the world of professional golf stands to produce benefits for former President Donald J. Trump’s family business by increasing the prospect of major tournaments continuing to be played at Trump-owned courses in the United States and perhaps abroad.

headline: An Unstoppable Verstappen Wins Again
abstract: A wire-to-wire victory for Max Verstappen in Barcelona gave Red Bull seven wins in seven starts, and renewed talk of a season sweep.
paragraph: Lewis Hamilton drove aggressively and overtook rivals, sometimes with apparent ease. George Russell gained several places by zipping up the run-off area at the start and held off a late challenge from Sergio Pérez. It was a great day for Mercedes.

headline: The Evolving, Enduring Superstardom of Yannick Noah
abstract: To the world, Noah is the last Frenchman to win his country’s Grand Slam tournament. In France, his legacy and life loom over every man who has played tennis.
paragraph: Yannick Noah was nervous.

headline: Tension Overshadows the Tennis Between Sabalenka and Svitolina
abstract: Players from Ukraine do not shake hands with players from Russia and Belarus. Aryna Sabalenka waited at the net anyway.
paragraph: In hindsight, this French Open was probably destined to come down to a moment like the one that unfolded Tuesday.

headline: Roger Craig, Teacher of an Era-Defining Pitch, Is Dead at 93
abstract: After winning three World Series as a player, Craig became a coach and spread the gospel of the split-fingered fastball, what one player of the time called “the pitch of the ’80s.”
paragraph: Roger Craig, who pitched or managed in five World Series and changed the face of pitching in the 1980s as the guru of the split-fingered fastball, died on Sunday. He was 93.

headline: MetLife Stadium Gets an N.H.L. Outdoor Doubleheader, of Sorts
abstract: Over two days in February 2024, the N.F.L. stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., will host the Rangers against the Islanders, and the Devils against the Flyers.
paragraph: Outdoor N.H.L. hockey will make its debut in New Jersey next year when MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford will host a four-team doubleheader of sorts in the league’s so-called Stadium Series.

headline: Stefanos Tsitsipas Picks Up Doubles Tennis and His Kid Brother
abstract: Tsitsipas is aiming to beat Carlos Alcaraz in Paris on Tuesday in a French Open quarterfinal, but what he really wants is to help turn his younger brother Petros into a doubles champion.
paragraph: Stefanos Tsitsipas already had a lot going on as he arrived at the French Open.

headline: Want a Class in Leadership Styles? Look to the N.B.A. Finals.
abstract: Experts in leadership say the differing styles of Miami’s Jimmy Butler and Denver’s Nikola Jokic show there’s no one right way to be a leader.
paragraph: A few weeks after Caleb Martin joined the Miami Heat, he didn’t yet have much social capital with his teammates. But he had been a backup player for most of his career who knew that it was important to get along with the stars — and Jimmy Butler, a six-time All-Star and the team’s leading scorer, was unquestionably Miami’s biggest.

headline: The Heat, a Long Shot in the Playoffs, Pull Even With Long Shots
abstract: Miami, usually outgunned by the Denver offense, made 17 3-pointers to even the N.B.A. finals at one game apiece.
paragraph: Michael Malone is generally the kind of coach who would leave a negative Yelp review after vacationing in Shangri-La. But his worry was warranted this time.

headline: Will Alcaraz and Djokovic Finally Get to Play Each Other at the French Open?
abstract: If everything goes right in the quarterfinals for Alcaraz and Djokovic, the two most dominant players on the men’s tour, the duel everyone has been waiting for will happen.
paragraph: Eight days ago, 128 men began competing in singles at the French Open. Pretty much everyone has been focused on two of them.

headline: For Claressa Shields, Repeat Titles Haven’t Come With Knockouts
abstract: It’s tougher in women’s boxing to get victories by stoppage, which forces champions like Shields to adapt their style.
paragraph: When Claressa Shields threw a looping right hand during her middleweight title defense in Detroit on Saturday night, the punch would sometimes make contact and either clip the jaw of the challenger, Maricela Cornejo, or bounce off her left shoulder.

headline: Nikola Jokic, an Elusive Superstar, Has a Hold on Denver
abstract: Jokic, the Nuggets center, may be the best player in the N.B.A., but he avoids the spotlight. Still, in his own way, he has endeared himself to a city hungry for someone to believe in.
paragraph: About two miles from downtown Denver, the yellows, oranges and reds of a spray-painted mural fill the cracked, gray cement wall of a building that houses a temporary employment agency. The mural rises about 20 feet and depicts an expressionless Nikola Jokic next to a much more emotive Jamal Murray, his eyes narrowed and arms extended as though he is wielding a bow and arrow.

headline: A Mets Hall of Fame Class That Specializes in Honesty
abstract: As the team continues to celebrate its history, Gary Cohen, Howie Rose, Al Leiter and Howard Johnson were honored for their contributions over the years.
paragraph: He sat in the audience watching it all, like a proud grandfather at a college graduation. Fred Wilpon, 86, had owned the Mets when their new class of Hall of Famers — Howard Johnson, Al Leiter and the broadcasters Gary Cohen and Howie Rose — made their marks with the team. At a news conference before the ceremony on Saturday, Wilpon beamed.

headline: The Exclusive, Elusive World of Real Tennis
abstract: “If you wanted to design a game that was going to put people off from playing it,” one court tennis enthusiast said, “you would probably design a real tennis court.”
paragraph: Up on the second floor, hidden behind the facade of a tall Haussmann building not far from the Arc de Triomphe, is the Jeu de Paume Club, the only active court tennis club in Paris.

headline: Sabalenka Skips French Open News Conference Citing Her Mental Health
abstract: The Belarusian player faced questions about the war earlier in the week from a Ukrainian reporter. On Friday, with the tournament’s blessing, she did not attend her postmatch news conference.
paragraph: Aryna Sabalenka’s day began with a routine demolition of Kamilla Rakhimova of Russia that propelled the world’s second-ranked player, who is from Belarus, into the second week of the French Open as expected.

headline: Churchill Downs to Cease Racing as It Investigates Deaths of Horses
abstract: The track, the home of the Kentucky Derby, is moving races to another location while officials look into why 12 thoroughbreds have died at Churchill Downs in recent weeks.
paragraph: Horse racing will be suspended at Churchill Downs and moved to a different Kentucky racetrack as federal and state regulators continue to investigate the deaths of 12 horses at Churchill in the past five weeks, the company said in a statement on Friday.

headline: A Negro Leagues Star Is Still Sharing His Story
abstract: A pastor for more than 50 years, William Greason, 98, occasionally tells tales of a lifetime ago, when he mentored Willie Mays and played in the last Negro World Series.
paragraph: The older pastor, wearing a long purple robe, ascended the steps to the pulpit. “God has always had a plan and a purpose for each of our lives,” the Rev. William H. Greason said in a slow, gentle voice. From the pews came affirmations of “Amen!” and “All right!”

headline: Coco Gauff Has a Chance to Play the Wise Veteran at the French Open
abstract: Gauff, now 19 and in her fifth season on the tour, took on Mirra Andreeva, who is 16 and the latest teenager to go on a tear in women’s tennis.
paragraph: Tennis moves fast.

headline: Claressa Shields Sets Aside Friendship in Goal of Dominating Her Sport
abstract: Shields, who is undefeated in professional boxing, faces Maricela Cornejo in Detroit on Saturday.
paragraph: The first time Claressa Shields and Maricela Cornejo went head-to-head, they co-starred in a YouTube video.

headline: One N.B.A. Finals Team Will Get a Trophy. But Will Either Get Respect?
abstract: Both the Denver Nuggets and the Miami Heat believe they have been disrespected and are using that as motivation as they compete for a championship.
paragraph: The Denver Nuggets’ mascot, Rocky, an anthropomorphic mountain lion with a lightning bolt for a tail, dragged a pickax as he stormed around, trying to figure out where all the chatter was coming from. He needed to quiet the voices. They were disrespecting his team.

headline: A Barcelona Star Chases Trophies and Answers
abstract: In her quest to become a “complete” player, Aitana Bonmatí wants to know everything. As she prepares for a fourth Champions League final, it’s working.
paragraph: Aitana Bonmatí always asks the same question. Every game Barcelona Femení plays generates a flood of performance data. The team’s fitness coaches know how far each player ran, how fast, how long. There is so much information, in fact, that they need two days to download it and tabulate it and parse it. Only then is it passed back to the squad.

headline: Churchill Downs Moves to Keep Unsound Horses Off the Track
abstract: After the deaths of a dozen thoroughbreds at the Louisville, Ky., track, officials are changing policies that may have incentivized trainers to race vulnerable horses.
paragraph: Churchill Downs, under scrutiny after 12 horses suffered fatal injuries in the past five weeks, on Thursday put in place measures meant to discourage trainers from running unsound horses.

headline: Ja Morant Gun Investigation Results Delayed During N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Commissioner Adam Silver said he could announce the findings now, but it would be “unfair” to the Denver Nuggets and Miami Heat, who are still competing.
paragraph: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver on Thursday said that the league would wait until the conclusion of the finals to announce the findings of its latest investigation into the behavior of Memphis Grizzlies guard Ja Morant, as well as any potential discipline of him.

headline: As Cable Model Struggles, M.L.B. Takes Over Padres Broadcasts
abstract: M.L.B. will retain San Diego’s broadcast team and will offer in-market streaming with no blackouts after Bally Sports failed to meet its financial commitments.
paragraph: In a move that could signify the beginning of a new era in how Major League Baseball games are distributed, the league is taking over production and distribution of all San Diego Padres games starting with the team’s game against the Miami Marlins on Wednesday night.

headline: Win or Lose, The French Get Behind Their Own
abstract: The French Open’s signature is the near-limitless abandon with which the French fans unite behind anyone who plays under the bleu-blanc-rouge.
paragraph: Had you been at Roland Garros around supper time Wednesday evening and heard the crowd of nearly 10,000 fans chanting Lucas Pouille’s name at a near deafening level, you would have assumed you had just missed a triumphant performance.

headline: Where Is the Pass Going?
abstract: Few aspects of basketball capture the joy of the game like great passes. Can you see the court like the pros?
paragraph: Few aspects of basketball capture the joy of the game like great passes. Can you see the court like the pros?

headline: At the French Open, Djokovic Storms the Court and Into Controversy, Again
abstract: In recent days, the Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic has inserted himself into the mounting international crisis in Kosovo.
paragraph: After everything that Novak Djokovic had put himself through over the past few years, the French Open began with the possibility, finally, of a Grand Slam tournament free of drama.

headline: Chelsea Says Executive Accused of Bullying Has Left the Club
abstract: A Premier League team confirmed the departure after an investigation into workplace behavior, but employees said they had received little information about its findings.
paragraph: Almost a year after one of England’s richest and most decorated soccer teams opened an investigation into a senior executive accused of workplace bullying so severe that several staff members said colleagues took mental health leave to escape it, the team, Chelsea F.C., confirmed that the executive has left the club.

headline: Galaxy Fire Their General Manager, Long a Target of Fan Anger
abstract: Last in the standings and facing a boycott from fans, the Los Angeles Galaxy ousted Chris Klein.
paragraph: When the world’s most famous soccer player, David Beckham, came to Major League Soccer in 2007, his arrival put the league on the map and affirmed the Los Angeles Galaxy’s status as the young league’s superteam. During Beckham’s tenure, the Galaxy played in three M.L.S. Cups, won two of them and exuded a Hollywood glamour that resonated around the world.

headline: Can These Russians Become Tennis’s Next Great Sister Act?
abstract: Women’s tennis was headlined for more than two decades by Serena and Venus Williams. On Tuesday, the teenagers Mirra and Erika Andreeva made their French Open debuts.
paragraph: Long day for the Andreeva family.

headline: Celtics Hit Another Dead End, With No Clear Path Forward This Time
abstract: A team with N.B.A. championship aspirations fell short against Miami. Tough calls and new contracts await.
paragraph: The curtains closed on Monday night for the Boston Celtics’s Jekyll and Hyde routine.

headline: A National Treasure on the Rise Is Hit With a Doping Allegation
abstract: A star Olympic runner from Australia was suspended over a positive drug test of a kind that critics have called alarmingly open to human error.
paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Few professional runners become household names. But in Australia, Peter Bol, a middle-distance runner of Sudanese descent, is something of a national hero.

headline: Congrats, You Made the French Open. You Get to Play Djokovic and Alcaraz.
abstract: Little-known players learned humbling lessons when they drew Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic in the first round of the French Open.
paragraph: Aleksandar Kovacevic did plenty of tossing and turning Sunday night before finally settling in for what he thought was about six hours of restless sleep.

headline: The Hockey Championship the U.S. Men Just Can’t Seem to Win
abstract: American men have achieved thrilling victories at the Olympics, but they haven’t won a world hockey championship in decades.
paragraph: After a strong start, the U.S. men’s hockey team was disappointingly eliminated from the world championship over the weekend. Again.

headline: In Third Place but Armed for a Run at the Top
abstract: The Yankees held steady as their starting rotation got healthy. With Luis Severino back, and Carlos Rodón on the way, there is reason to expect brighter days ahead.
paragraph: Luis Severino was in a playful mood late Saturday afternoon at Yankee Stadium. The day had gone so well that he mused about pitching only in the sunshine. He felt so strong that he guessed he could throw his fastball 103 miles per hour. He was dressed for success, and he knew it.

headline: Women’s Tennis Suddenly Has a Big(ish) Three
abstract: Iga Swiatek, Elena Rybakina and Aryna Sabalenka have been winning just about everything important lately, emerging as a potential triumvirate unseen in the women’s game for about a decade.
paragraph: Iga Swiatek, Elena Rybakina and Aryna Sabalenka have won a combined five Grand Slam singles titles. Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic have won 64.

headline: Bill Wambsganss Was Many Things. But He Wasn’t a ‘Succession’ Spoiler.
abstract: In the HBO series finale, Tom Wambsgans beat out three competitors at once, just like the Cleveland second baseman who turned the only unassisted triple play in World Series history.
